revision.text:
A '''carriage dispute''' is a disagreement over the right to "carry", that is, retransmit, a [[broadcasting|broadcaster's]] signal. Carriage disputes first occurred between broadcasters and [[cable television|cable]] companies and now include [[direct broadcast satellite]] and other [[multichannel video programming distributors]].
These disputes often involve financial compensation – what the distributor pays the [[television station]] or [[television network|network]] for the right to carry the signal – as well as what channels the distributor is permitted or required to retransmit and how the distributor offers those channels to its subscribers.<ref name="McMurria">{{cite book|url=http://faculty.fordham.edu/andersen/hypercommercialism.pdf|title=Battleground: The Media Volume 1|last=McMurria|first=John|publisher=Greenwood Press|year=2008|isbn=0313341672|editor1-last=Andersen|editor1-first=Robin|location=Westport, CT|pages=69–76|chapter=Cable Carriage Disputes|editor2-last=Grey|editor2-first=Jonathan}}</ref> While most carriage disputes are resolved without controversy or notice,<ref name="NYT DirecTVvsViacom">{{cite news|last=Stelter|first=Brian|title=DirecTV-Viacom Dispute May Affect Access for 20 Million Customers|url=http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/07/10/directv-viacom-dispute-may-affect-access-for-20-million-customers/|accessdate=12 July 2012|newspaper=New York Times|date=July 10, 2010}}</ref> others have involved programming [[blackout (broadcasting)|blackouts]], both threatened and real, as well as strident public relations campaigns. Carriage disputes have occurred both in the United States and internationally.
==History== The history of carriage disputes can be seen as having two distinct circumstances: the first involving [[terrestrial television|over-the-air broadcasters]], whose signals can be received with an antenna; the second involving broadcasters transmitting via cable, satellite or other means—but not over the air. In the United States, the first led to a quagmire of legal disputes involving the [[Federal Communications Commission]] and the courts, shifting regulations, and questions over copyright law – all revolving around the basic question of whether a carrier has an inherent right to retransmit an over-the-air signal. Broadcasters accused carriers of being "leeches", making money off of programming content that they contributed nothing to produce.<ref name=Robichaux>{{cite book|last=Robichaux|first=Mark|title=Cable Cowboy: John Malone and the Rise of the Modern Cable Business|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|location=Hoboken, New Jersey|isbn=978-0-471-23639-9|pages=56}}</ref> Carriers countered that their role was largely passive, because they were merely redistributing freely available signals more widely.<ref name=Seiden>{{cite book|last=Seiden|first=Martin H.|title=Cable Television U.S.A.: an Analysis of Government Policy|year=1972|publisher=Praeger Publishers|location=New York, London|pages=150}}</ref> By contrast, carriage disputes involving broadcasters who do not use the public airwaves, while representing many high-profile encounters, have raised fewer legal and policy questions, playing out largely at the negotiation table and in the [[court of public opinion]].
The legal precedent for carriage disputes dates back to 1934 legislation, which required a broadcaster to get permission before using programming from another broadcaster. The law was later applied to cable companies, as well.<ref name="FCC Guide"/> In the 1950s, cable companies operating in the [[western United States]] began retransmitting broadcast signals for the benefit of customers situated too far from the station's transmitter to receive programs with an antenna. Stations objected that they were not being compensated for this retransmission or that they were having to compete with more distant stations that duplicated their content. From February 15, 1966 to December 18, 1968, the [[United States]] Federal Communications Commission barred cable companies from importing non-local broadcast signals into the top 100 television markets – while allowing cable companies to petition for exceptions. After an interim period, the FCC partially lifted these restrictions in 1972, eliminating them entirely by the end of the decade.<ref name=McMurria /><ref>{{cite book|last=Seiden|first=Martin H.|title=Cable Television U.S.A.: an Analysis of Government Policy|year=1972|publisher=Praeger Publishers|location=New York, London|pages=95–96}}</ref>
The issue was finally resolved with the 1992 [[Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act]]. Among its provisions, the act mandated that distributors [[must carry]] local stations who make their signal available for free, but must also get [[retransmission consent]] before a signal can be retransmitted. Mandatory retransmission consent gave broadcasters the ability to seek compensation from distributors and established the basis for carriage disputes going forward. At first, the larger broadcasters negotiated not for higher fees, but for inclusion of their newer, lesser known, non-terrestrial channels. [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]], for example, obtained distribution for [[FX (TV channel)|FX]]; [[NBC]] for [[CNBC]].<ref name=McMurria /><ref name="FCC Guide">{{cite web|title=Cable Carriage of Broadcast Stations|url=http://www.fcc.gov/guides/cable-carriage-broadcast-stations|work=Guides|publisher=Federal Communications Commission|accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> The practice complicated carriage disputes by making bundled tiers not just a marketing choice, but a contractual obligation.<ref name="NPR: history of cable bill">{{cite news|title=Episode 488: The Secret History Of Your Cable Bill|newspaper=National Public Radio: Planet Money|date=September 27, 2013}}</ref>
Carriage disputes have since increased both in intensity and frequency. According to the American Television Alliance, a television viewer advocacy group, there were eight blackouts of various lengths in 2010, 94 in 2014, 123 in 2015, and 212 in late 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/hollywood/la-fi-ct-cbs-dish-blackout-20171121-story.html|title=Millions of Dish customers lose CBS signals, face Thanksgiving without network's football|last=James|first=Meg|date=November 21, 2017|work=latimes.com|access-date=2017-11-21|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hz4lDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA86&lpg=PA86&dq=programming+blackouts+over-the-top+services&source=bl&ots=4UqTJaLdaq&sig=df3TJEgPRNG0EoFbCcXmUrOJcaY&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiSsrT8itDXAhVJqVQKHeoQCIsQ6AEIQjAD#v=onepage&q=programming%20blackouts%20over-the-top%20services&f=false|title=Communication Technology Update and Fundamentals: 15th Edition|last=Grant|first=August E.|last2=Meadows|first2=Jennifer H.|date=2016-11-03|publisher=Taylor & Francis|year=|isbn=9781134987658|location=|pages=86|language=en}}</ref>
=== Examples === [[File:Fox-Time Warner dispute.jpg|thumb|A Time Warner Cable advertisement from its December 2009 carriage dispute with Fox. Designed to resemble a [[ransom note]], the ad continued: “We’re standing up to Fox. Don’t let Fox hold your TV hostage.”<ref name="The New Yorker TW vs Fox">{{cite news|last=Collins|first=Lauren|title=King Kong Vs. Godzilla|url=http://www.newyorker.com/talk/2010/01/11/100111ta_talk_collins|accessdate=11 January 2013|newspaper=The New Yorker|date=January 11, 2010}}</ref>]] The 2009 dispute between Time Warner Cable and Fox is an example of a carriage dispute involving an over-the-air broadcaster. The dispute pitted the second largest United States cable system against one of the four major U.S. television networks, whose broadcasts included the popular prime time series ''[[American Idol]]'' and [[National Football League]] games. Fox's then-parent company, [[News Corporation]] (which has since spun off the network and its cable channels to [[21st Century Fox]]), reportedly sought a monthly fee of $1 per subscriber; Time Warner offered 20 to 25 cents. Both companies mounted aggressive public relations campaigns, including dedicated websites and advertising. Fox suggested that viewers look into alternatives to Time Warner, including satellite and [[Verizon]]'s [[Verizon Fios|Fios]] service. Time Warner Cable countered that it was trying to reign in expenses that would ultimately be paid by subscribers. The companies ultimately settled close to the deadline, and, as is typical with carriage disputes, did not disclose the terms. The deal encouraged other over-the-air broadcasters to seek higher retransmission payments, thereby putting upward pressure on cable and satellite bills.<ref name="TVNews Fox TW">{{cite news|last=Littleton|first=Cynthia|title=Fox, TW go down to wire|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118013117?refcatid=14|accessdate=7 July 2012|newspaper=TV News|date=December 27, 2009}}</ref><ref name="MDN TW Fox Fallout">{{cite news|last=Friedman|first=Wayne|title=Fallout: Time Warner, Fox Deal May Set Benchmark For Retrans Disputes| url=http://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/120010/|accessdate=7 July 2012|newspaper=MediaDailyNews|date=January 4, 2010}}</ref><ref name="LATimes--ViacomDirecTV talks continue">{{cite news|last=Flint|first=Joe|title=Viacom and DirecTV continue to negotiate but remain far apart|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-et-ct-viadirect-20120712,0,4033378.story|accessdate=13 July 2012|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=July 12, 2012}}</ref><ref name="PhilInquirer Viacom-DirecTV">{{cite news|last=Fernandez|first=Bob|title=Viacom-DirecTV cost dispute highlights concern over pay-TV's future|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/business/20120712_Viacom-DirecTV_cost_dispute_highlights_concern_over_pay-TV_s_future.html|accessdate=13 July 2012|newspaper=Philadelphia Inquirer|date=July 12, 2012}}</ref>
The 2012 dispute between [[DirecTV]] and [[Viacom]] is an example of a dispute involving a non-terrestrial broadcaster. Viacom's cable/satellite channels, including [[Comedy Central]], [[Nickelodeon]] and [[MTV]], were blacked out for some 20 million DirecTV subscribers, who together represented about 20 percent of all U.S. households who subscribed to cable or satellite. DirecTV claimed Viacom was seeking a 30 percent fee hike, about $1 billion over five years. Viacom countered that while its channels represented 20 percent of total DirecTV viewing, the broadcaster received only 5 percent of the distributor's license fees. DirecTV argued that Viacom made too much of its content available for free on the Internet. Viacom responded that the practice was a marketing tool, although it pared that content back after the blackout. Also mentioned as a point of contention was Viacom's bundling of its co-owned channels – making them available to distributors only as a package rather than individually.<ref name="NYT DirecTVvsViacom" /><ref name="USAToday DirecTVvViacom">{{cite news|last=Snider|first=Mike|title=Viacom channels are off DirecTV systems|url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/industries/telecom/story/2012-07-11/DirecTV-Viacom-channels/56149394/1|accessdate=12 July 2012|newspaper=USAToday|date=July 12, 2012}}</ref> In a sign of the increasing pressure on carriers to limit subscriber fees, DirecTV competitors did not mount advertising campaigns to attract disgruntled customers, and some competitors issued statements of support.<ref name="wsjViacom">{{cite news|last1=Ramachandran|first1=Shalini|last2=Jannarone|first2=John|title=Viacom to Restore DirecTV Channels|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10000872396390444464304577538492034772130|accessdate=20 July 2012|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=July 20, 2012}}</ref> Viacom and DirecTV resolved the dispute with a seven-year contract nine days later. Financial terms were not disclosed, though one analyst estimated Viacom would receive around $2.85 per subscriber, up from $2.25. In a first for Viacom, the company also agreed to give DirecTV customers access to live feeds on mobile devices.<ref name="LATimes DirecTV Viacom settle">{{cite news|last=Flint|first=Joe|title=DirecTV and Viacom reach deal, end blackout|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-0721-ct-directv-viacom-settle-20120721,0,3067559.story|accessdate=22 July 2012|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=July 20, 2012}}</ref>
Occasionally, a carriage dispute can last for months or even years. In September 2012, Time Warner Cable and the [[National Football League]] ended a nine-year dispute primarily over [[NFL Network]], and later, [[NFL Network#NFL RedZone Channel|NFL RedZone Channel]]. The deal followed an earlier settlement between the NFL and Cablevision, making Time Warner the last major holdout. Time Warner had offered to carry NFL Network on a narrower sports tier and argued that the relative scarcity of annual games–eight, expanded to 13–did not justify the cost. SNL Kagan estimated the average subscriber fee at 95 cents per month.<ref name="Adweek:NFL-Time Warner">{{cite news|last=Crupi|first=Anthony|title=NFL Network in Carriage Talks With Time Warner Cable|url=http://www.adweek.com/news/television/nfl-network-carriage-talks-time-warner-cable-133867|accessdate=6 July 2012|newspaper=Adweek|date=August 4, 2011}}</ref><ref name="Bloomberg NFL-TW resolved">{{cite news |last=Soshnick |first=Scott |title=NFL Reaches Agreement With Time Warner on NFL Network, RedZone |url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-09-21/nfl-said-to-have-deal-with-time-warner-for-nfl-network-redzone |accessdate=7 January 2013 |newspaper=Bloomberg News |date=September 22, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130107204400/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-09-21/nfl-said-to-have-deal-with-time-warner-for-nfl-network-redzone |archivedate=7 January 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref name="NYT-TW NFL settle">{{cite news|last=Sandomir|first=Richard|title=Time Warner Will Carry NFL Network|url=http://fifthdown.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/09/21/time-warner-is-said-to-agree-to-carry-nfl-network/|accessdate=7 January 2013|newspaper=New York Times|date=September 21, 2012}}</ref> Some prolonged disputes are influenced by outside people and organizations. In 2003, New York City Mayor [[Michael R. Bloomberg]] helped arrange a deal between Cablevision and [[YES Network]], which had kept many [[New York Yankees]] baseball games from being seen by some 3 million local subscribers for the first year of YES Network's run.<ref>{{cite news|last=Sandomir|first=Richard|title=BASEBALL; Cablevision Agrees to Carry the YES Network|accessdate=12 July 2012|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/03/13/sports/baseball-cablevision-agrees-to-carry-the-yes-network.html|newspaper=New York Times|date=March 13, 2003}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Terranova|first=Justin|title=YES Network marks 10th anniversary|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/sports/more_sports/yes_and_it_counts_8Hk0ERY7IHzVFUo94EmuON|accessdate=12 July 2012|newspaper=New York Post|date=March 23, 2012}}</ref> In 2006, [[EchoStar]] dropped the female-oriented channel [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]] for a competing channel, [[Oxygen (TV channel)|Oxygen]]. While Lifetime is partially owned by Disney, which in turn owns ESPN and ABC, the deciding factor for contract renewal came less from the parent company's clout than from a letter writing campaign spurred by the [[National Organization for Women]], the [[YWCA]], and other groups.<ref name="McMurria" />
Blackouts have occasionally extended to broadcasters' websites. In the summer of 2013, CBS blocked access to all Time Warner Cable subscribers, whether or not they lived in the disputed regions. In 2014, Viacom blocked streaming video access to Cable One customers. Broadcasters argued that the practice closes a loophole: if distributors are to feel pressure from their subscribers, those subscribers shouldn't be able to view the content elsewhere. The [[Federal Communications Commission]] Chairman [[Tom Wheeler]] said the practice of extending blackouts to the Internet is of broad concern.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-et-ct-fcc-chairman-expresses-concern-about-tv-networks-blocking-websites-20140520-story.html#navtype=outfit|title = FCC chairman expresses concern about TV networks blocking websites|last = Flint|first = Joe|date = May 20, 2014|work = Los Angeles Times|accessdate = }}</ref>
A February 2015 carriage dispute between [[Fox Sports 1]] and [[AT&T U-verse]] produced a rare example of a partial blackout. When the parties couldn't agree, the channel did not disappear entirely from the U-verse lineup. Instead, the blackout only extended to some programing, including [[NASCAR]] events, [[Major League Soccer]] matches, and [[USGA]] golf events. FS1 had added most of these events after its launch and maintained it was only seeking to get paid for the added value provided. AT&T U-verse called the additional fees "unreasonable".<ref name=variety-uverseblackout>{{cite web|title=Fox Sports 1, AT&T In Dispute Over Fees For Nascar, Golf, Soccer|url=https://variety.com/2015/tv/news/fox-sports-1-att-in-dispute-over-fees-for-nascar-golf-soccer-1201443261/|website=Variety|accessdate=15 April 2015}}</ref>
==== Aereo ==== {{main|American Broadcasting Companies v. Aereo}}
In 2012, a carriage dispute of a different sort arose between [[Aereo]], a small New York-based program distributor, and several major broadcasters, including [[CBS]], [[NBC]], [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]], [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]], [[Univision]] and [[PBS]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.eff.org/document/second-circuit-injunction-opinion-wnet-v-aereo|title = Second Circuit Injunction Opinion in WNET v. Aereo|date = August 30, 2012|publisher = U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit (posted by the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]]).}}</ref> Aereo used banks of small antennas to receive over-the-air signals from broadcasters, then made those signals available to subscribers via the Internet. But unlike other distributors, the company argued that, as an "antenna technology" company, it was exempt from paying retransmission consent fees, just as is any home viewer employing an antenna. Broadcasters countered that the Aereo service went beyond the conventional antenna because it both recorded programs for later viewing and charged subscribers a monthly fee, thus acting as a middleman. Aereo won its case in all but one lower court proceeding, including an April 1, 2013 ruling by the [[Second Circuit Court of Appeals]].<ref name="NYT Aereo">{{cite news|last=Stelter|first=Brian|title=Aereo Wins a Court Battle, Dismaying Broadcasters|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/02/business/media/aereo-wins-in-appeals-court-setting-stage-for-trial-on-streaming-broadcast-tv.html|accessdate=9 April 2013|newspaper=New York Times|date=April 1, 2013}}</ref><ref name="NYT Carr-Aereo">{{cite news|last=Carr|first=David|title=Spreading Disruption, Shaking Up Cable TV|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/18/business/media/barry-dillers-aereo-service-challenges-cable-television.html|accessdate=9 April 2013|newspaper=New York Times|date=March 17, 2013}}</ref><ref name=NPR-Aereo>{{cite news|last=Bobkoff|first=David|title=Startup CEO Wields Small Antenna In TV Streaming Battle|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/alltechconsidered/2013/04/12/176979130/Startup-CEO-Wields-Small-Antenna-In-TV-Streaming-Battle|accessdate=12 April 2013|newspaper=National Public Radio|date=April 12, 2013}}</ref><ref name="LA Times: Case to the People">{{cite news|last=Flint|first=Joe|title=Aereo takes its case to the people as broadcasters press on in court|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-et-ct-aereo-ad-campaign-20130417,0,1535952.story|accessdate=17 April 2013|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=April 17, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Aereo injunction in Utah">{{cite news|last=Johnson |first=Ted |title=Utah Federal Judge Halts Aereo in Salt Lake City and Denver |newspaper=''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' |url=https://variety.com/2014/biz/news/utah-federal-judge-halts-aereo-in-salt-lake-city-and-denver-1201112853/ |date=February 19, 2014 }}</ref><ref name="Aereo stay injunction">{{cite news|last=Johnson |first=Ted |title=Aereo Granted Two-Week Reprieve As It Appeals Utah Ruling |url=https://variety.com/2014/biz/news/aereo-granted-two-week-reprieve-as-it-appeals-utah-ruling-1201120992/ |newspaper=''Variety'' |date=February 25, 2014 }}</ref> But in a 6-3 decision issued on June 25, 2014, the Supreme Court sided with the broadcasters, ruling that Aereo had violated copyright laws.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/supreme-court-rules-against-startup-aereo-saying-it-is-violating-copyright-laws/2014/06/25/59756f88-fc6b-11e3-8176-f2c941cf35f1_story.html|title = Supreme Court rules against start-up Aereo, saying it is violating copyright laws|last = Markon|first = Jerry|date = June 25, 2014|work = The Washington Post|accessdate = }}</ref>
=== Proposed legislation === Some legislators have sought to dampen the effects of carriage disputes on subscribers by giving more power to the Federal Communications Commission. In 2010, then Senator [[John Kerry]] introduced draft legislation that would have given the FCC more oversight responsibility, with the power to monitor negotiations and impose binding arbitration if it deems discussions between broadcasters and distributors are not being carried out in [[wikt:good faith|good faith]].<sup>[13]</sup> In 2013, Representatives [[Anna Eshoo]] and [[Zoe Lofgren]] introduced the Video CHOICE (Consumers Have Options in Choosing Entertainment) Act, which would have enabled the FCC to prohibit channel blackouts during a dispute. The bill would also have prohibited broadcast channels from negotiating for carriage of its non-broadcast channels.<ref name="LA Times: Proposed Bills">{{cite news|last=Flint|first=Joe|title=Proposed bills seek to rewrite media rulebook|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-et-ct-proposed-bills-media-rules-20131212,0,2826769.story|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=December 12, 2013}}</ref>
On the same day the Video CHOICE legislation was introduced, Representative [[Steve Scalise]] reintroduced legislation first drafted in 2011: the Next Generation Television Marketplace Act. The legislation, more far-reaching than CHOICE, would have repealed key provisions of the 1992 Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act, including "[[Must-carry|must carry]]" and [[retransmission consent]] requirements, as well as [[Compulsory license|compulsory copyright licenses]] stemming from 1976 copyright law. The legislative intent was that carriage negotiations for broadcast stations should play out on the same terms as those for non-terrestrial channels. Both bills, while given only narrow chances of passage, were generally welcomed by distributors and criticized by broadcasters.<ref name="LA Times: Proposed Bills" /><ref name="B&C: Scalise bill">{{cite news|last=Eggerton|first=John|title=Scalise Reintroduces Video Reform Bill|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/washington/scalise-reintroduces-video-reform-bill/127941|newspaper=Broadcast & Cable|date=December 12, 2013}}</ref><ref name="B&C: Compulsory licenses">{{cite news|last=Eggerton|first=John|title=Padden: Get Rid of Compulsory License and Retrans|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/washington/padden-get-rid-compulsory-license-and-retrans/60412|newspaper=Broadcast & Cable|date=July 20, 2012}}</ref>
==Tradeoffs, consequences== As with all negotiations, carriage disputes involve tradeoffs for both parties. Distributors must weigh the effect of the carriage fees they pay on both their revenues and the fees they pass on to subscribers. Distributors also risk antagonizing their subscribers if they drop one or more channels from their lineup. For their part, broadcasters risk losing viewers, which in turn can reduce revenues from commercials and per-subscriber carriage fees. Financial consequences can ensue. Dish Network lost 156,000 customers in the fourth quarter of 2011 after a carriage dispute with Fox resulted in a loss of Fox Sports programming in October.<ref name="Variety Dish Network loses">{{cite news|last=Lowry|first=Tom|title=Dish Network loses subscribers|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118032821|accessdate=6 July 2012|newspaper=Variety|date=February 24, 2011}}</ref> AMC Networks' stock dropped by nearly five percent after the network's programming was dropped by Dish at the end of June 2012.<ref name="Variety:AMC">{{cite news|last=Goldsmith|first=Jill|title=AMC Networks stock drops 5%: News of AT&T carriage dispute on top of Dish feud hits company|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/sns-201206281659reedbusivarietynvr1118056089-20120628,0,3626937.story|accessdate=6 July 2012|newspaper=Variety|date=June 28, 2012}}</ref>
For distributors, much of the calculation hinges on whether programming content is so compelling that it is worth the retransmission fee. Sports programming provides a good example of how the calculation may favor either party.
In a 2013 dispute between CBS and Time Warner Cable, CBS's bargaining position improved as the National Football League season approached. In the wake of the settlement, the broadcaster increased its per [[subscriber]] fee from an estimated $.58 to between $1 and $2, setting a new standard for retransmission fees commanded by over-the-air broadcasters. CBS also retained digital rights to its contents for resale to online distributors. The agreement was expected to earn the broadcaster an estimated $1 billion to $2 billion in additional revenues by 2017.<ref name="NYT: CBS triumphant">{{cite news|last=Carter|first=Bill|title=CBS Returns, Triumphant, to Cable Box|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/03/business/media/cbs-and-time-warner-cable-end-contract-dispute.html?_r=0|accessdate=3 September 2013|newspaper=New York Times|date=September 2, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://advanced-television.com/2013/08/30/analysis-changing-economics-of-retrans/|title = Analysis: Changing economics of retrans|date = September 2, 2013|website = Advanced Television}}</ref><ref name="Reuters CBS squeezes">{{cite news|title=CBS win squeezes Time Warner Cable's margins: analysts|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2013/09/03/us-cbs-timewarner-idINBRE9810O720130903|accessdate=3 September 2013|newspaper=Reuters|date=September 3, 2013|author=Grover, Ronald|author2=Baker, Liana B.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Sherman |first=Alex |title=CBS Deal Ends Time Warner Cable Blackout Ahead of NFL |date=September 3, 2013 |url=http://mobile.bloomberg.com/news/2013-09-02/cbs-reaches-accord-to-end-blackout-on-time-warner-cable.html |publisher=Bloomberg |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016073837/http://mobile.bloomberg.com/news/2013-09-02/cbs-reaches-accord-to-end-blackout-on-time-warner-cable.html |archivedate=2013-10-16 |df= }}</ref><ref name="HollywoodRep-TW CBS could set standard">{{cite news|last=Ben Block|first=Alex|title=How the Time Warner Cable, CBS Strandoff Could Set the TV Standard|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/how-time-warner-cable-cbs-613713|accessdate=3 September 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=August 26, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title = Bold Play by CBS Fortifies Broadcasters|date = September 6, 2013|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/07/business/media/bold-play-by-cbs-fortifies-broadcasters.html?pagewanted=1&_r=0&hp|publisher = |last = Carter|first = Bill|work=The New York Times}}</ref>
On the other hand, some [[regional sports networks]] have seemingly overplayed their hand.<ref name=":0" /> [[CSN Houston]], a partnership between the [[Houston Rockets]], the [[Houston Astros]] and [[Comcast]], was subsequently placed under bankruptcy protection after its October 2012 debut. While Comcast carried the channel, DirecTV, Dish Network and other competitors did not, citing the fee: $3.40 per month, one of the highest of any comparable channel. As a result, CSN Houston was unavailable to about 60% of the region's households. The owner of the Astros subsequently dropped high-salaried players, and the team finished the 2013 season with the worst record in baseball.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/houston-teams-want-potential-buyers-for-sports-channel-kept-confidential-1405368455|title = Houston Teams Want Potential Buyers for Sports Channel Kept Secret|last = Stetch|first = Katy|date = July 14, 2014|work = The Wall Street Journal|accessdate = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.bizjournals.com/houston/morning_call/2014/03/comcast-sportsnet-houstons-bankruptcy-case-headed.html|title = Comcast SportsNet Houston's bankruptcy case headed to mediation|last = Pulsinelli|first = Olivia|date = March 21, 2014|work = Houston Business Journal|accessdate = }}</ref>
In January 2013, [[Time Warner Cable Arena|Time Warner Cable]] signed an $8.35 billion, 25-year contract with the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] to carry and resell the Dodger-owned [[SportsNet LA]]. But in the 2014 season, the channel was only carried by TWC itself and a few smaller distributors, leaving about 70% of the region uncovered. TWC had reportedly asked other distributors for an initial $4 to $5 per-month per-subscriber, with carriage fees increasing yearly over the length of the contract. Those distributors, most notably DirecTV, balked at the terms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-et-ct-dodgers-channel-launch-20140224,0,4524006.story|title=Dodger channel debuts Tuesday but much of region will be shut out|work=Los Angeles Times|first=Joe|last=Flint|date=February 24, 2014|accessdate=February 26, 2014}}</ref><ref name="lat-directv">{{cite web|title=Time Warner Cable says talks with DirecTV for Dodgers channel are over|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-et-ct-time-warner-cable-says-talks-with-directv-for-dodger-channel-are-over-20140403,0,6994648.story|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=4 April 2014}}</ref> Los Angeles Times business reporter Joe Flint called the standoff a potentially "definitive moment for the world of sports programming, as the industry realizes that exorbitantly priced television deals can backfire."<ref name="Flint 7/14">{{Cite news|url = http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-et-ct-dodgers-tv-standoff-20140718-story.html?track=rss#page=1|title = Standoff over Dodgers games could be defining moment in sports TV|last = Flint|first = Joe|date = July 17, 2014|work = Los Angeles Times|accessdate = }}</ref> Other teams with whose regional sports networks did not gain traction include the [[Kansas City Royals]] and [[Minnesota Twins]].<ref name=":0" />
Some smaller cable companies, relying on revenues from broadband subscriptions, have been more willing to drop a bundled service, even at the cost of fewer television subscribers. In 2014, for example, [[Suddenlink]], the seventh largest U.S. cable provider, entered into a lengthy dispute with Viacom, which continued even though Suddenlink lost 32,600 television subscribers over the first three months. But the company's net income was up 65 percent over the same period the previous year because it retained most of those subscribers as broadband customers.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/09/business/media/betting-against-the-cable-bundle.html|title = Provider’s Dispute With Viacom Highlights Skirmish Over the Cable Bundle|last = Steel|first = Emily|date = March 8, 2015|work = |access-date = }}</ref> The conflict was only resolved in May 2017, after [[Altice USA]] purchased Suddenlink and came to a new carriage agreement with Viacom which also encompassed Altice's New York metro Optimum service.
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
== External links == * American Television Alliance Blackout List: a spreadsheet linked from [http://www.americantelevisionalliance.org/media-center/ the organization's media page] giving a running tally from 2010
[[Category:Cable television in the United States]] [[Category:Satellite television]] [[Category:Broadcast law]] [[Category:Television terminology]]

revision.text:
'''Computational semantics''' is the study of how to automate the process of constructing and reasoning with [[semantics|meaning representations]] of [[natural language]] expressions.<ref>Blackburn, Patrick, and Johan Bos. "[https://dialnet.unirioja.es/descarga/articulo/499187.pdf Computational semantics]." Theoria: An International Journal for Theory, History and Foundations of Science (2003): 27-45.</ref> It consequently plays an important role in [[natural language processing]] and [[computational linguistics]].
Some traditional topics of interest are: [[semantic analysis (linguistics)|construction of meaning representation]]s, semantic [[underspecification]], [[anaphora (linguistics)|anaphora]] resolution,<ref>Basile, Valerio, et al. "[https://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=%22meaning+representation%22+%22computational+semantics%22+%22underspecification%22+%22anaphora%22+%22scope+resolution%22&btnG=&hl=en&as_sdt=0%2C47# Developing a large semantically annotated corpus]." LREC 2012, Eighth International Conference on Language Resources and Evaluation. 2012.</ref> [[presupposition]] projection, and [[Quantifier (linguistics)|quantifier]] scope resolution. Methods employed usually draw from [[Formal semantics (linguistics)|formal semantics]] or [[statistical semantics]]. Computational semantics has points of contact with the areas of [[lexical semantics]] ([[word sense disambiguation]] and [[semantic role labeling]]), discourse semantics, [[knowledge representation]] and [[automated reasoning]] (in particular, [[automated theorem proving]]). Since 1999 there has been an [[Association for Computational Linguistics|ACL]] special interest group on computational semantics, SIGSEM.
==See also== * [[Discourse representation theory]] * [[Minimal recursion semantics]] * [[Natural language understanding]] * [[Semantic compression]] * [[Semantic parsing]] * [[Semantic Web]] * [[SemEval]] * [[WordNet]]
==Further reading== * Blackburn, P., and Bos, J. (2005), ''Representation and Inference for Natural Language : A First Course in Computational Semantics'', CSLI Publications. {{ISBN|1-57586-496-7}}. * Bunt, H., and Muskens, R. (1999), ''Computing Meaning, Volume 1'', Kluwer Publishing, Dordrecht. {{ISBN|1-4020-0290-4}}. * Bunt, H., Muskens, R., and Thijsse, E. (2001), ''Computing Meaning, Volume 2'', Kluwer Publishing, Dordrecht. {{ISBN|1-4020-0175-4}}. * Copestake, A., Flickinger, D. P., Sag, I. A., & Pollard, C. (2005). [https://web.archive.org/web/20120717034844/http://lingo.stanford.edu/sag/papers/copestake.pdf Minimal Recursion Semantics. An introduction]. In Research on Language and Computation. 3:281–332. * Eijck, J. van, and C. Unger (2010): Computational Semantics with Functional Programming. Cambridge University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-521-75760-7}} * Wilks, Y., and Charniak, E. (1976), ''Computational Semantics: An Introduction to Artificial Intelligence and Natural Language Understanding'', North-Holland, Amsterdam. {{ISBN|0-444-11110-7}}.
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.sigsem.org/ Special Interest Group on Computational Semantics (SIGSEM)] of the Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL) * [http://let.uvt.nl/research/ti/sigsem/iwcs/ IWCS] - International Workshop on Computational Semantics (endorsed by SIGSEM) * [http://staff.science.uva.nl/~mdr/ICoS/ ICoS] - Inference in Computational Semantics (endorsed by SIGSEM) * [http://blog.wolfram.com/2016/12/22/the-semantic-representation-of-pure-mathematics/ Wolfram Group] - Semantic Representation of Pure Mathematics
[[Category:Computational linguistics]] [[Category:Natural language processing]] [[Category:Semantics]] [[Category:Computational fields of study]]
{{comp-ling-stub}} {{semantics-stub}}

page.title: Declaration on the Elimination of Violence Against Women

revision.text:
{{Infobox document |document_name = The Declaration on the Elimination of Violence Against Women |image = |image_width = |image_caption = |date_created = 1993 |date_ratified = 20 December 1993 |location_of_document = |writer = |signatories = |purpose = [[Women's rights]] |wikisource = }} {{Violence against women}}'''The Declaration on the Elimination of Violence Against Women''' was adopted without vote{{Cite web |url = https://www.un.org/depts/dhl/resguide/r48_en.shtml |title = RESOLUTIONS: General Assembly, 48th session |work = un.org |accessdate = May 14, 2014 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140116222203/http://www.un.org/depts/dhl/resguide/r48_en.shtml |archivedate = January 16, 2014 |df = }} by the [[United Nations General Assembly]] in its resolution 48/104 of 20 December 1993. Contained within it is the recognition of "the urgent need for the universal application to women of the rights and principles with regard to equality, security, liberty, integrity and dignity of all human beings".{{Cite web |url= http://www.un-documents.net/a48r104.htm |title=A/RES/48/104 – Declaration on the Elimination of Violence against Women – UN Documents: Gathering a body of global agreements |work=un-documents.net |accessdate=February 24, 2010 }} The resolution is often seen as complementary to, and a strengthening of, the work of the [[Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women]]{{Cite web |url= https://www.un.org/womenwatch/daw/cedaw/ |title=Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women |work=un.org |accessdate=February 24, 2010 }} and [[Vienna Declaration and Programme of Action]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.refworld.org/cgi-bin/texis/vtx/rwmain?page=topic&tocid=459d17822&toid=459b17a82&docid=3ae6b39ec&skip=O |title=Vienna Declaration and Programme of Action, Part II, paragraf 38 |work=refworld.org |accessdate=June 24, 2017 }} It recalls and embodies the same rights and principles as those enshrined in such instruments as the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]] and Articles 1 and 2 provide the most widely used definition of [[violence against women]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.unece.org/fileadmin/DAM/stats/gender/vaw/about.html |title=UNECE Gender Statistics – About Violence Against Women |work=unece.org |accessdate=June 3, 2017 }} As a consequence of the resolution, in 1999, the General Assembly, led by the representative from the Dominican Republic, designated 25 November as the [[International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women]]. ==Background== The international recognition that women have a right to a life free from violence is a recent one. Historically, their struggles with violence, and with the impunity that often protects the perpetrators, is linked with their fight to overcome discrimination. Since its founding the United Nations has concerned itself with the [[Division for the Advancement of Women|advancement of women's rights]],{{Cite web|url=https://www.un.org/events/women/iwd/2007/pdf/background.pdf|title=Ending Impunity for Violence Against Women and Girls|publisher=United Nations Department of Public Information|date=March 2007|accessdate=2010-01-03}} but did not specifically target the high rates of female targeted violence until 1993. One of the aims of the resolution was to overturn the prevailing governmental stance that violence against women was a private, domestic matter not requiring state intervention. To mark [[International Women's Day]] on 8 March 1993, General Secretary, [[Boutros Boutros-Ghali]], issued a statement in preparation of the declaration explicitly outlining the UN's role in the 'promotion' and 'protection' of women's rights:
"The struggle for women's rights, and the task of creating a new United Nations, able to promote peace and the values which nurture and sustain it, are one and the same. Today - more than ever - the cause of women is the cause of all humanity."{{Cite web |url= https://www.un.org/womenwatch/feature/iwd/1993/ |title=Secretary-General, in International Women's Day message, sys promotion and protection of women's rights central to work of United Nations |date=1993 |work=un.org (WomenWatch) |accessdate=24 February 2010 }}
==Definition of Violence Against Women== Articles 1 and 2 of the resolution provide the most widely used definition of violence against women.
Article One: For the purposes of this Declaration, the term "[[violence against women]]" means any act of gender-based violence that results in, or is likely to result in, physical, sexual or psychological harm or suffering to women, including threats of such acts, coercion or arbitrary deprivation of liberty, whether occurring in public or in private life.
Article Two: Violence against women shall be understood to encompass, but not be limited to, the following: :(a) Physical, sexual and psychological violence occurring in the family, including [[Battery (crime)|battering]], [[child sexual abuse|sexual abuse of female children]] in the household, [[dowry]]-related violence, [[marital rape]], [[female genital mutilation]] and other traditional practices harmful to women, non-spousal violence and violence related to [[Sexual exploitation|exploitation]]; :(b) Physical, sexual and [[psychological abuse|psychological violence]] occurring within the general community, including [[rape]], [[sexual abuse]], [[sexual harassment]] and intimidation at work, in educational institutions and elsewhere, [[Human trafficking|trafficking]] in women and [[forced prostitution]]; :(c) Physical, sexual and psychological violence perpetrated or condoned by the State, wherever it occurs.
==Special Rapporteur on Violence Against Women== As a consequence of the declaration on 4 March 1994, the Commission on Human Rights adopted Resolution 1994/45{{Cite web |url=http://ap.ohchr.org/documents/E/CHR/resolutions/E-CN_4-RES-1994-45.doc |title=1994/45. Question of integrating the rights of women into the human rights mechanisms of the United Nations and the elimination of violence against women |work=ohchr.org |accessdate=June 24, 2017 }} in which it decided to appoint [[Radhika Coomaraswamy]] as its first [[United Nations Special Rapporteur]] on [[Special Rapporteur on Violence Against Women|Violence Against Women]], including its causes and consequences. The Special Rapporteur has a mandate to collect and analyse data from governments, treaty bodies, specialized agencies, NGOs, and other interested parties, and to respond effectively to such information. Furthermore, they also have a role in making recommendations on an international, national and regional level, as well as liaising with other Special Rapporteurs, special representatives, working groups and independent experts of the Commission on Human Rights.{{Cite web |url= http://www2.ohchr.org/english/issues/women/rapporteur/ |title=Special Rapporteur on violence against women, its causes and consequences |work=www2.ohchr.org |accessdate=February 24, 2010 }} On 18 June 2009 the [[United Nations Human Rights Council]] appointed [[Rashida Manjoo]] as the third incumbent of the role after the tenure of her predecessor, Dr. Yakin Erturk, came to an end.{{Cite web |url=http://www.ohchr.org/EN/NewsEvents/Pages/DisplayNews.aspx?NewsID=52&LangID=E |title=Violence Against Women: South African legal expert takes over as new UN Special Rapporteur |work=www.ohchr.org |accessdate=June 3, 2017 }} ==Problems== Many advocates of Women's Rights as Human Rights have expressed concerns that much of the ground gained by the declaration has been threatened by the rise of more conservative forces within the international community.{{Cite web |url=http://www.awid.org/eng/Library/Violence-against-Women |title=Violence against Women |work=awid.org |last=Reilly |first=Niamh |date=2008-02-12 |accessdate=June 24, 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714121709/http://www.awid.org/eng/Library/Violence-against-Women |archivedate=2014-07-14 |df= }} In March 2003, during a meeting of the [[UN Commission on the Status of Women]] the delegate from Iran objected to the inclusion of a paragraph that called on governments to "condemn violence against women and refrain from invoking any custom, tradition, or religious consideration to avoid their obligations with respect to its elimination as set out in the Declaration of the Elimination of Violence against Women." Representatives from Egypt, Pakistan, Sudan and US also raised objections; making it the first ever diplomatic failure at the UN Commission on the Status of Women.{{Cite news |url= http://www.womensenews.org/story/international-policyunited-nations/030424/un-pact-sinks-issue-violence-against-women |title=U.N. Pact Sinks on Issue of Violence Against Women | Women's eNews |work=womensenews.org |last=Freeburg |first=Emily |date=2003-04-23 |accessdate=February 24, 2010 }} ==Campaigns== Each year, the [[International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women]] marks the start of [[16 Days of Activism against Gender-based Violence]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.who.int/violence_injury_prevention/violence/global_campaign/16_days/en/ |title=16 Days of Activism Against Gender Violence |work=who.int |accessdate=June 24, 2017 }} Human Rights organisations such as [[Center for Women's Global Leadership]],{{Cite web |url=http://16dayscwgl.rutgers.edu/ |title=16 Days of Activism Against Gender-Based Violence Campaign |work=rutgers.edu |accessdate=June 3, 2017 }} [[Unifem]], Women Won't Wait, Women for a Change, [[Women's Aid]], and other groups join together to speak out against gender violence and to promote the rights and principles of the declaration. On 10 April 2009, [[Amnesty International]] held a demonstration in [[Narayangarh, Chitwan|Narayanghat]], [[Nepal]], to highlight the plight of women's rights activists after the Nepalese state failed to protect two activists from violent attacks and, finally, their murder.{{Cite web |url=https://www.amnesty.org.uk/press-releases/nepal-two-womens-rightss-rightss-rightss-rightss-rightss-rights-human-rights |title=Nepal: Two Women's rights's rightss rights's rights's rights's rights human rights activists murdered after government fails to protect them from violent attacks |date=April 10, 2009 |work=amnesty.org.uk |accessdate=June 24, 2017 }} Despite ratifying the declaration, Nepal had failed to abide by Article 4-c which asserts the clear obligation of states to:
"Exercise due diligence to prevent, investigate and, in accordance with national legislation, punish acts of violence against women, whether those acts are perpetrated by the State or by private persons."
==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.un.org/womenwatch/daw/ United Nations Division for the Advancement of Women] {{DEFAULTSORT:Declaration On The Elimination Of Violence Against Women}} [[Category:United Nations General Assembly resolutions]] [[Category:Works about violence against women]] [[Category:Women's rights]] [[Category:1993 in law]] [[Category:1993 in the United Nations]] [[Category:Proclamations]] [[Category:1993 in women's history]] [[Category:December 1993 events]]

{{Infobox writing system |name=Ditema tsa Dinoko |altname=Isibheqe Sohlamvu |type=[[Featural]] [[syllabary]] |languages=[[Southern Bantu languages]] |fam1= [[Litema]], Amabheqe [[ideographs]] (Izimpawu zesiNtu) |sample=Isibheqe_sohlamvu.jpg |imagesize=200px }}
'''Ditema tsa Dinoko''' ([[Sesotho]] for "Ditema syllabary"), also known by its [[Zulu language|IsiZulu]] name, ''Isibheqe Sohlamvu'', and various other related names in different languages,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isibheqe.org |title=IsiBheqe |publisher=isibheqe.org |date=23 August 2015 |accessdate=16 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://linguistics.org.za/LSSASAALASAALT-ConferenceProgramme2015.pdf |title=Isibheqe Sohlamvu: An Indigenous Writing System for Southern Bantu Languages |publisher=linguistics.org.za |date=22 June 2015 |accessdate=16 September 2015}}</ref> is a [[Constructed script|constructed writing system]] (specifically, a [[featural]] [[syllabary]]) designed for the [[Southern Bantu languages]] (for example, for [[Sesotho]], [[Tswana language|Setswana]], [[Zulu language|IsiZulu]], [[Xhosa language|IsiXhosa]], [[SiSwati]], [[Phuthi language|SiPhuthi]], [[Tsonga language|Xitsonga]], [[Makhuwa language|EMakhuwa]], [[Ngoni language|ChiNgoni]], [[Lozi language|SiLozi]], or [[Venda language|Tshivenḓa]]), developed from antecedent [[ideographic]] traditions of the Southern African region. Its visual appearance is inspired by these, including the traditional [[litema]] arts style.<ref>[https://matthewdea.com/blog/2017/5/12/writing-systems-of-africa Writing Systems] (12 May 2017) "Perhaps the most contemporary and creative African script is known as Ditema Tsa Dinoko (Isibheqe Sohlamvu in Zulu). This script can be used to write any Southern Bantu language, such as Sesotho, Zulu, and Tswana. The Southern Bantu languages are found in South Africa, Botswana, Mozambique, and Zimbabwe. Created within the past three years by linguists, programmers, and designers, this special writing system is inspired by traditional litema art of Lesotho." See also e.g.: {{cite web|url=http://miami2015.designmiami.com/design-galleries/view/southern-guild4 |title=Isibheqe cabinets |publisher=Design Miami |date= |accessdate=2015-11-23}}</ref>
The Ditema / Isibheqe syllabary has the capacity to represent the full phonological range of these ''sintu'' languages (in the [[Nguni languages|Nguni]], [[Sotho-Tswana languages|Sotho-Tswana]], [[Venda language|Venḓa]], [[Tsonga language|Tsonga]] and [[Guitonga language (Mozambique)|Tonga-Inhambane]] groups) consistently under one [[orthography]].<ref name=isibheqe.org>{{cite web|url=http://www.isibheqe.org |title=Isibheqe Sohlamvu/Ditema tsa Dinoko |author=isibheqe.org |year=2015 |publisher=isibheqe.org }}</ref>
This includes languages that are unstandardised in the [[Latin alphabet]] such as the [[Pulana language|East Sotho languages]] (Sepulana, Sekutswe and Hipai), or the [[Tekela languages]], which, with the exception of [[Swazi language|SiSwati]], are not official languages. Orthographic support for these languages is for instance evidenced in the ''ingungwana'' [[grapheme]], which indicates [[nasal vowel|vowel nasality]] — a feature of Tekela languages.
[[File:Ditema-tsa-dinoko_s_c_(1).jpg|thumb|left|''Ditema tsa Dinoko'', read left-to-right. The three syllables of first word are clustered, with the third syllable on the bottom]]
==Description== The script operates as a [[syllabary]], as each freestanding symbol represents a [[syllable]], with [[graphemes]] for consonant and vowel sounds combined together into syllable blocks (''amabheqe''), in a similar fashion to [[Hangeul]]. When the syllable being represented is not a [[syllabic consonant|syllabic nasal]], these symbols are formed from a triangular or [[Chevron (insignia)|chevron-shaped]] grapheme representing the [[Nucleus (syllable)|nucleus]] of the syllable, with the attached ''ongwaqa'' or consonant graphemes representing the [[onset (linguistics)|onset]] of the syllable or its mode of articulation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.isibheqe.org/ingcazo.html |title=Ingcazo |website=isibheqe.org |access-date=2016-09-11}}</ref> Syllabic nasals are represented as circles that fill the whole ''ibheqe'' or syllable block.
[[File:Xilo_Vhathu_Ho_tlêtse.jpg|thumb|right|''The construction of the syllables of three words in different languages: <Xilo> [ʃiːlɔ] "thing" in Xitsonga, <Vhathu> [βaːtʰu] "people" in Tshivenḓa, <Ho tlêtse> [hʊt͜ɬ’ɛːt͜s’ɪ] "It is full" in Sesotho.]]
==Vowels==
The vowel graphemes (''onkamisa'') form the basis of each ''ibheqe'' or syllable block, as the nucleus of each syllable, with the ''ongwaqa'' or consonant graphemes positioned in and around them.
The direction of each ''ibheqe'' indicates the quality of the vowel for each of the seven vowel [[phonemes]]:
• ''Intombi'', the upward facing triangle: /i/
• ''Isoka'', the downward facing triangle: /a/
• ''Umkhonto'', the upward facing chevron: /u/
• The leftward facing triangle: /ɛ/
• The rightward facing triangle: /ɔ/
• The leftward facing chevron: /e/
• The rightward facing chevron: /o/
There is an eighth "vowel" represented by the downward facing chevron, which is an ''empty vowel'', and is mostly used for foreign words to represent a standalone consonant, often as a [[syllable coda]], which does not occur in sintu languages having CV phonology.
[[File:Onkamisa (AmaBheqe).jpg|''Onkamisa'', vowel graphemes.]]
The apex of the triangle or chevron corresponds to vowel height or frontedness, with [[high vowel|high vowels]] /i/ and /u/ pointing upwards and the [[low vowel]] /a/ pointing downwards. Likewise, the [[front vowel|front vowels]] /ɛ/ and /e/ point leftwards and the [[back vowel|back vowels]] /ɔ/ and /o/ point rightwards.
[[File:Onkamisa (Emlonyeni).jpg]]
Vowel nasality is indicated with the ''ingungwana'' grapheme, which is a solid dot outside the triangle separated from the apex, as in the word ''phãsi'' below:
[[File:Ingungwana (Vowel Naslity).jpg|thumbnail|left]]
{| class="wikitable" !English !''down/below'' |- !Zunda !''phansi'' | [[File:Pʰaːntsʼi.jpg|thumbnail|left|pʰaːntsʼi]] |- !Tekela !''phãsi'' | [[File:Pʰãːsi.jpg|thumbnail|left|pʰãːsi]] |}
==Consonants==
Consonants (''ongwaqa'') are composed of one or more graphemes, at least one of which indicates the place and manner of articulation and thereafter they represent co-articulations or onset clusters and the articulatory mode, whether it be [[voiced]], [[prenasalised]], [[implosive]], [[ejective]], [[modal voice|modal]], or a combination thereof.
The position of the consonant graphemes largely corresponds to the [[place of articulation]]:
• [[labial consonant|Labials]] and [[Nasal consonant|nasals]] are positioned outside the triangle at the apex.
• [[Alveolar consonant|Alveolars]] are across the middle of the triangle from side to side.
• [[Velar consonant|Velars]] and [[Palatal consonant|palatals]] are at the base.
• [[lateral consonant|Laterals]] are outside the triangle on one side.
• [[dental consonant|Dentals]] are two lines across the triangle from side to side, parallel to each other.
The shape of the consonant grapheme corresponds to the [[manner of articulation]]:
• Curved lines indicate [[fricatives]].
• Their straight line counterparts in the same positions indicate [[plosives]].
• [[Approximants]] and [[Trill consonant|trills]] are represented with two lines either parallel or at a right angle to each other, with a [[Flap consonant|tap or flap]] being the latter arrangement, one line bisecting the other at its centrepoint without crossing it.
• [[Retroflex]] whistled consonants and [[postalveolar]] fricatives are represented as loops.
• [[Nasal consonant|Nasals]] are represented as circles at the apex of the triangle. Lines inside the circles distinguish the nasals from each other.
• [[click consonant|Clicks]] are a bottomless hourglass shape.
• Syllabic laterals and trills are represented with duplication of the ordinary lateral and trill graphemes.
Syllabic nasals or ''amaqanda'' are unique in that they occupy the entire ''ibheqe'' space as circles. They are distinguished from each other with lines inside them that operate according to the same principles as above.
These graphemes can combine with each other in an order in accordance with the [[phonotactics]] of sintu languages, and they also can combine with the articulatory mode graphemes.
[[File:Ongwaqa.png]]
==Articulatory mode==
[[File:Articulatory mode.png|thumb|right|]]
There are three graphemic markers of articulatory mode:
• For unvoiced consonants, a solid dot within the triangle indicates a glotallised ([[ejective consonant|ejected]]) consonant or a modal click consonant.
• For voiced consonants the solid dot inside the triangle indicates an [[implosive]] consonant or, in the case of languages where there are no implosives, a modal consonant.
• The absence of the dot indicates [[breathy voice]] in the case of voiced consonants, and [[aspirated consonant|aspiration]] in the case of voiceless consonants.
• ''Uphimbo'', or the voicing line, running from the apex of the triangle to the base (or until inline with the ends of the chevron), indicates consonant [[voiced consonant|voicing]].
• If the voicing line occurs as the only ''ungwaqa'' in the ''ibheqe'', it indicates a [[voiced glottal fricative]] /ɦ/.
• In languages that distinguish between breathy voiced and modal nasals/trills, the voicing line indicates breathy voice when occurring with these consonant graphemes.
• [[Prenasalized consonant|Prenasalised consonants]] are marked with an open circle at the apex of the triangle called ''ingungu''. These occur with other consonant graphemes, and are distinct from the [[bilabial nasal]] /m/ that occurs on its own. No additional lines need be added to the ''ingungu'' when it occurs with other ''ongwaqa'' as the place of articulation is given by them and need not be marked in the nasal grapheme.
• For clicks, the ''ingungu'' marks a [[nasal click consonant]], with the prenasalised clicks (e.g. <nkq>) requiring the addition of a solid dot (glottalisation), in which case the ''ingungu'' denotes prenasalisation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isibheqe.org/ingcazo |title=Incazo Yohlelo |publisher=isibheqe.org |date=23 August 2015 |accessdate=16 September 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} {{List of writing systems}} [[Category:Writing systems of Africa]] [[Category:Syllabary writing systems]] [[Category:Artificial scripts]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=August 2017}}
'''Dòmhnall Iain MacLeòid''' (born 1943) is a writer, editor, and journalist in [[Scottish Gaelic]]. He was born in [[Ardhasaig]] in [[Harris, Scotland|Harris]].<ref>{{cite web|ainm=|sloinneadh=|ùghdar_eile=|ùghdaran_eile=|ceann-là=|title=Fiosrachadh beatha - An t-Oll. Dòmhnall Iain MacLeòid, Tobar an Dualchais|url=http://www.tobarandualchais.co.uk/gd/person/418#|ceann-là_inntrigidh=|foillsichear=|duilleagan=|language=[[Scottish Gaelic]], English}}</ref> He obtained a PhD from [[University of Glasgow|the University of Glasgow]] in 1969; his thesis was entitled ''Twentieth Century Gaelic literature: a description, comprising critical study and a comprehensive bibliography''. He was the co-editor of [[Gairm]] with [[Derick Thomson|Ruaraidh MacThòmais]]. He was a [[lecturer]] in the Celtic Department, [[University of Glasgow]].<ref>{{cite web|ainm=|sloinneadh=|ùghdar_eile=|ùghdaran_eile=|ceann-là=|title=20mh linn – Eachdraidh na Roinne, Sgeul na Gàidhlig aig Oilthigh Ghlaschu|url=http://sgeulnagaidhlig.ac.uk/sreath-dheilbh-luchd-obrach/|ceann-là_inntrigidh=|foillsichear=|duilleagan=|language=[[Scottish Gaelic]], English}}</ref>
== Publications == * ''Dorcha tro Ghlainne: taghadh de sgeulachdan-goirid'' (Gairm, Glaschu, 1970), ed. * ''Dualchas an Aghaidh nan Creag: The Gaelic Revival 1890-2020'' (Clò-beag, Inbhir Nis, 2011)

{{short description|Study of the psychosocial and cultural factors involved in the origin of language and the development of linguistic universals}} {{Linguistics}} {{Evolutionary biology}} '''Evolutionary linguistics''' is a subfield of [[psycholinguistics]] that studies the psychosocial and cultural factors involved in the [[origin of language]] and the development of [[linguistic universal]]s.<ref name="Croft 2008">{{cite journal | last = Croft | first = William |date=October 2008 | title = Evolutionary Linguistics | journal = Annual Review of Anthropology | volume = 37 | pages = 219–234 | publisher = Annual Reviews | doi = 10.1146/annurev.anthro.37.081407.085156 | url = http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/abs/10.1146/annurev.anthro.37.081407.085156}}</ref> The main challenge in this research is the lack of empirical data: spoken [[language]] leaves practically no traces. This led to the abandonment of the field for more than a century, despite the common origins of language hinted at by the relationships among individual languages established by the field of [[historical linguistics]]. Since the late 1980s, the field has been revived in the wake of progress{{citation needed|date=October 2017}} made in the related fields of [[biolinguistics]], [[psycholinguistics]], [[neurolinguistics]], [[evolutionary anthropology]], [[evolutionary psychology]], [[universal grammar]], and [[cognitive science]].
==History== Inspired by the natural sciences, especially by [[biology]], [[August Schleicher]] (1821–1868) became the first to compare changing languages to evolving [[species]].<ref>Taub, Liba. ''Evolutionary Ideas and "Empirical" Methods: The Analogy Between Language and Species in the Works of Lyell and Schleicher.'' British Journal for the History of Science 26, pages 171–193 (1993)</ref> He introduced the representation of language families as an evolutionary tree (''Stammbaumtheorie'') in articles published in 1853.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Schleicher| first = August | title = Darwinism tested by the science of language : Free Download | url = https://archive.org/details/darwinismtestedb69schl | publisher = Internet Archive | date = 1869 | accessdate = 11 December 2013 }}</ref> ''Stammbaumtheorie'' proved very productive for [[comparative linguistics]], but did not solve the major problem of studying the [[origin of language]]: the lack of [[fossil]] records. Some scholars abandoned the question of the origin of language as unsolvable. Famously, the ''[[Société Linguistique de Paris]]'' in 1866 refused to admit any further papers on the subject. [[Joseph Jastrow]] published a gestural theory of the evolution of language in the seventh volume of ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'', 1886.<ref name="Jastrow 1886">{{cite journal |author=Jastrow J |title=The Evolution of Language |journal=Science |volume=7 |issue=176S |pages=555–557 |year=1886 |pmid=17778380 |doi=10.1126/science.ns-7.176S.555 |jstor=1761264}}</ref>
The field re-appeared in 1988 in the ''[[Linguistic Bibliography]]'' as a subfield of [[psycholinguistics]]. In 1990, [[Steven Pinker]] and [[Paul Bloom (psychologist)|Paul Bloom]] published their paper "Natural Language and Natural Selection"<ref name="Pinker Bloom 2011">{{cite journal|last1=Pinker|first1=Steven|last2=Bloom|first2=Paul|title=Natural language and natural selection|journal=Behavioral and Brain Sciences| volume=13|issue=4| year=2011|pages=707–727 |doi=10.1017/S0140525X00081061|url=http://www.phonetik.uni-muenchen.de/~hoole/kurse/hs_evolution/pinkerbloom_bbs_13_4_1990.pdf}}</ref> which strongly argued for an [[adaptationist]] approach to language origins. Development strengthened further with the establishment (in 1996) of a series of conferences on the Evolution of Language (subsequently known as "Evolang"), promoting a scientific, multi-disciplinary approach to the issue, and interest from major academic publishers (e.g., the ''Studies in the Evolution of Language'' series has appeared with [[Oxford University Press]] since 2001)<ref>{{Cite web | title = Oxford Studies in the Evolution of Language | url = http://ukcatalogue.oup.com/category/academic/series/language/sel.do | publisher = Oxford University Press | accessdate = 11 December 2013 }}</ref> and from scientific journals.
==Recent developments== Evolutionary linguistics as a field is rapidly emerging as a result of developments in neighboring disciplines. To what extent language's features are determined by genes, a hotly debated dichotomy in linguistics, has had new light shed upon it by the discovery of the ''[[FOXP2]]'' [[gene]].<ref name="Scharff 2005">{{cite journal |author=Scharff C, Haesler S |title=An evolutionary perspective on FoxP2: strictly for the birds? |journal=Curr. Opin. Neurobiol. |volume=15 |issue=6 |pages=694–703 |date=December 2005 |pmid=16266802 |doi=10.1016/j.conb.2005.10.004 |url=|last2=Haesler }}</ref><ref name="Scharff 2011">{{cite journal |author=Scharff C, Petri J |title=Evo-devo, deep homology and FoxP2: implications for the evolution of speech and language |journal=Philos. Trans. R. Soc. Lond. B Biol. Sci. |volume=366 |issue=1574 |pages=2124–40 |date=July 2011 |pmid=21690130 |pmc=3130369 |doi=10.1098/rstb.2011.0001 |url=|last2=Petri }}</ref> An [[KE family|English family]] with a severe, heritable [[Developmental verbal dyspraxia|language dysfunction]] was found to have a defective copy of this gene.<ref name="Vargha-Khadem 2007">{{cite book | last1 = Vargha-Khadem | first1 = Faraneh | last2 = Liegeois | first2 = Frederique | title = From speech to gene: The KE family and the FOXP2 | editors = Stein Braten | work = On Being Moved : From Mirror Neurons to Empathy | publisher = John Benjamins Publishing Company | year = 2007 | location = Amsterdam | pages = 137–146 | isbn = 9789027252043| oclc=643718628}}</ref><ref name="Vargha-Khadem 1995">{{cite journal |author=Vargha-Khadem F, Watkins K, Alcock K, Fletcher P, Passingham R |title=Praxic and nonverbal cognitive deficits in a large family with a genetically transmitted speech and language disorder |journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. |volume=92 |issue=3 |pages=930–3 |date=January 1995 |pmid=7846081 |pmc=42734 |doi= 10.1073/pnas.92.3.930|url=|last2=Watkins |last3=Alcock |last4=Fletcher |last5=Passingham }}</ref> Mutations of the corresponding gene in mice (''FOXP2'' is fairly well conserved; modern humans share the same allele as [[Neanderthal]]s)<ref name="Krause 2007">{{cite journal |vauthors=Krause J, Lalueza-Fox C, Orlando L |title=The derived FOXP2 variant of modern humans was shared with Neandertals |journal=Curr. Biol. |volume=17 |issue=21 |pages=1908–12 |date=November 2007 |pmid=17949978 |doi=10.1016/j.cub.2007.10.008 |url= |displayauthors=etal }}</ref><ref name="Rizzi 2012">{{cite journal |author=Rizzi E, Lari M, Gigli E, De Bellis G, Caramelli D |title=Ancient DNA studies: new perspectives on old samples |journal=Genet. Sel. Evol. |volume=44 |issue= |pages=21 |year=2012 |pmid=22697611 |pmc=3390907 |doi=10.1186/1297-9686-44-21 |url=|last2=Lari |last3=Gigli |last4=De Bellis |last5=Caramelli }}</ref> cause reductions in size and vocalization rate. If both copies are damaged, the [[Purkinje layer]] (a part of the [[cerebellum]] that contains better-connected neurons than any other) develops abnormally, [[runt]]ing is more common, and pups die within weeks due to inadequate lung development.<ref name="Shu 2007">{{cite journal | author = Shu W, Lu MM, Zhang Y, Tucker PW, Zhou D, Morrisey EE | title = Foxp2 and Foxp1 cooperatively regulate lung and esophagus development | journal = Development | volume = 134 | issue = 10 | pages = 1991–2000 | date=May 2007| pmid = 17428829 | doi = 10.1242/dev.02846 | url = | issn = | last2 = Lu | last3 = Zhang | last4 = Tucker | last5 = Zhou | last6 = Morrisey }}</ref> Additionally, higher presence of ''FOXP2'' in songbirds is correlated to song changes, with [[Downregulation and upregulation|downregulation]] causing incomplete and inaccurate song imitation in [[Zebra Finch|zebra finches]]. In general, evidence suggests that the protein is vital to neuroplasticity. There is little support, however, for the idea that ''FOXP2'' is 'the grammar gene' or that it had much to do with the relatively recent emergence of syntactical speech.<ref name="Diller 2009">{{cite book | last1 = Diller | first1 = Karl C. |last2 = Cann | first2 =Rebecca L. |title = Evidence Against a Genetic-Based Revolution in Language 50,000 Years Ago |editors= Rudolf Botha and Chris Knight| work= The Cradle of Language|series = Oxford Series in the Evolution of Language |year = 2009 |publisher = Oxford University Press |location = Oxford. |isbn = 978-0-19-954586-5 | oclc = 804498749 | pages =135–149}}</ref>
Another controversial dichotomy is the question of whether human language is solely human or on a continuum with (admittedly far removed) [[Animal communication|animal communication systems]]. Studies in [[ethology]] have forced researchers to reassess many claims of uniquely human abilities for language and speech. For instance, [[Tecumseh Fitch]] has argued that the [[Larynx#Descended larynx|descended larynx]] is not unique to humans. Similarly, once held uniquely human traits such as formant perception, combinatorial phonology and compositional semantics are now thought to be shared with at least some nonhuman animal species. Conversely, [[Derek Bickerton]] and others argue that the advent of abstract words provided a mental basis for analyzing higher-order relations, and that any communication system that remotely resembles human language utterly relies on cognitive architecture that co-evolved alongside language.
As it leaves no fossils, language's form and even its presence are extremely hard or impossible to deduce from physical evidence. Computational modeling is now widely accepted as an approach to assure the internal consistency of language-evolution scenarios. Approximately one-third of all papers presented at the 2010 Evolution of Language conference<ref>{{Cite web | title = Evolang8 - Program | url = http://www.let.uu.nl/evolang2010.nl/evolang8program.html | publisher = | date = 2010 | accessdate = 11 December 2013 }}</ref> rely at least in part on computer simulations.
==Approaches== One original researcher in the field is [[Luc Steels]], head of the research units of Sony CSL in [[Paris]] and the AI Lab at the [[Vrije Universiteit Brussel]]. He and his team are currently investigating ways in which artificial agents self-organize languages with natural-like properties and how meaning can co-evolve with language. Their research is based on the hypothesis that language is a [[complex adaptive system]] that emerges through adaptive interactions between agents and continues to evolve in order to remain adapted to the needs and capabilities of the agents. This research has been implemented in [[fluid construction grammar]] (FCG), a formalism for construction grammars that has been specially designed for the origins and evolution of language. The approach of computational modeling and the use of robotic agents grounded in real life is claimed to be theory independent. It enables the researcher to find out exactly what cognitive capacities are needed for certain language phenomena to emerge. It also focuses the researcher in formulating hypotheses in a precise and exact manner, whereas theoretical models often stay very vague.
Some linguists, such as [[John McWhorter]], have analyzed the evolution and construction of basic [[communication]] methods such as [[pidgin]]ization and [[creolization]].<ref name="McWhorter 2001">{{Cite book | last1 = McWhorter | first1 = John H. | title = The power of Babel : a natural history of language | date = 2001 | publisher = Times Books | location = New York | isbn = 978-0-7167-4473-3 | oclc = 46564796 }}</ref>
"Nativist" models of "[[universal grammar]]" are informed by [[linguistic universals]] such as the existence of [[pronoun]]s and [[demonstrative]]s, and the similarities in each language's process of [[nominalization]] (the process of [[verb]]s becoming [[noun]]s) as well as the reverse, the process of turning nouns into verbs.<ref name="Deutscher 2005">{{Cite book | last1 = Deutscher | first1 = Guy | title = The unfolding of language : an evolutionary tour of mankind's greatest invention | date = 2005 | publisher = Metropolitan Books | location = New York | isbn = 978-0-8050-7907-4 | oclc = 57311730 }}</ref> This is a purely descriptive approach to what we mean by "[[natural language]]" without attempting to address its emergence.
Finally there are those archaeologists and evolutionary anthropologists—among them Ian Watts,<ref name="Watts 2009">{{cite book |last = Watts | first = Ian |title=Red Ochre, Body Painting, and Language: Interpreting the Blombos Ochre |editors= Rudolf Botha and Chris Knight| work= The Cradle of Language|series = Oxford Series in the Evolution of Language |year = 2009 |publisher = Oxford University Press |location = Oxford. |isbn = 978-0-19-954586-5 | oclc = 804498749 | pages =62–92}}</ref> Camilla Power<ref name="Power 2009">{{cite book |last = Power| first = Camilla |title=Sexual Selection Models for the Emergence of Symbolic Communication: Why They Should be Reversed |editors= Rudolf Botha and Chris Knight| work= The Cradle of Language|series = Oxford Series in the Evolution of Language |year = 2009 |publisher = Oxford University Press |location = Oxford. |isbn = 978-0-19-954586-5 | oclc = 804498749| pages= 257–280}}</ref> and [[Chris Knight (anthropologist)|Chris Knight]] (co-founder with [[James Hurford]] of the EVOLANG series of conferences)—who argue that 'the origin of language' is probably an insoluble problem. In agreement with [[Amotz Zahavi]],<ref name="Zahavi 1993">{{cite journal |author=Zahavi A |title=The fallacy of conventional signalling |journal=Philos. Trans. R. Soc. Lond. B Biol. Sci. |volume=340 |issue=1292 |pages=227–30 |date=May 1993 |pmid=8101657 |doi=10.1098/rstb.1993.0061 |url=}}</ref> Knight argues that language—being a realm of patent fictions—is a theoretical impossibility in a Darwinian world, where signals must be intrinsically reliable. If we are going to explain language's evolution, according to this view, we must tackle it as part of a wider one—the evolutionary emergence of [[symbolic culture]] as such.<ref name="Knight 2009">{{Cite book | last1 = Knight| first1 =Chris| title=The origins of symbolic culture| editors = Ulrich J Frey; Charlotte Störmer; Kai P Willführ| work = Homo novus : a human without illusion | date = 2010 | publisher = Springer | location = Berlin ; New York | isbn = 978-3-642-12141-8 | oclc = 639461749| url = http://www.chrisknight.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2007/09/The-Origins-of-Symbolic-Culture.pdf |pages = 193–211 }}</ref>
==EVOLANG Conference== The Evolution of Language International Conferences<ref>{{Cite web | title = Evolution of Language International Conferences - Conference Details | url = http://evolang.org/ | publisher = evolang | accessdate = 11 December 2013}}</ref> have been held biennially since 1996. {{columns-list|colwidth=22em| # 1996 [[Edinburgh University|Edinburgh]]:<ref name="Evolang 1">{{Cite web | title = Volume issued after the Edinburgh Conference (1996) | url = http://www.infres.enst.fr/confs/evolang/edinbook.html | publisher = | accessdate = 11 December 2013 }}</ref><ref name="Hurford 1998">{{Cite book | last1 = Hurford | first1 = James R. | last2 = Studdert-Kennedy | first2 = Michael. | last3 = Knight | first3 = Chris | title = Approaches to the evolution of language : social and cognitive base | date = 1998 | publisher = Cambridge University Press | location = Cambridge, UK ; New York | isbn = 978-0-521-63964-4 | oclc = 37742390 }}</ref> # 1998 [[London]]:<ref name="Evolang 2">{{Cite web | title = Volume issued after the London Conference (1998) | url = http://www.infres.enst.fr/confs/evolang/Londonbook.html | publisher = | accessdate = 12 December 2013 }}</ref><ref name=" Knight 2000">{{Cite book | last1 = Knight | first1 = Chris | last2 = Studdert-Kennedy | first2 = Michael. | last3 = Hurford | first3 = James R. | title = The Evolutionary emergence of language : social function and the origins of linguistic form | date = 2000 | publisher = Cambridge University Press | location = Cambridge ;
