revision.text:
{{Latin grammar|sidebar}} '''Latin syntax''' is the part of [[Latin]] grammar that covers such matters as word order, the use of cases, tenses and [[grammatical mood|moods]], and the construction of simple and compound sentences.
The study of Latin syntax in a systematic way was particularly a feature of the late 19th century, especially in Germany. For example, in the 3rd edition of ''[[Basil Lanneau Gildersleeve|Gildersleeve]]'s Latin Grammar'' (1895), the reviser, Gonzalez Lodge, mentions 38 scholars whose works have been used in its revision; of these 31 wrote in German, five in English and two in French. (The English scholars include [[Henry John Roby|Roby]] and [[Wallace Lindsay|Lindsay]]).
In the twentieth century, the German tradition was continued with the publication of two very comprehensive grammars: the ''Ausführliche Grammatik der lateinischen Sprache'' by Raphael Kühner and Karl Stegmann (1912, first edition 1879), and the ''Lateinische Grammatik'' by Manu Leumann, J.B. Hofmann, and Anton Szantyr (revised edition Munich 1977, first edition 1926). Among works published in English may be mentioned E.C. Woodcock's ''A New Latin Syntax'' (1959). More recently, taking advantage of computerised texts, three major works have been published on Latin word order, one by the American scholars Andrew Devine and Laurence Stephens (2006),<ref>Devine & Stephens (2006).</ref> and two (adopting a different approach) by the Czech scholar Olga Spevak (2010 and 2014).<ref>Spevak (2010); Spevak (2014).</ref>
==Latin word order== {{main|Latin word order}} Latin word order is relatively free. The verb may be found at the beginning, in the middle, or at the end of a sentence; an adjective may precede or follow its noun (''vir bonus'' or ''bonus vir'' both mean 'a good man');<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 431.</ref> and a genitive may precede or follow its noun ('the enemies' camp' can be both ''hostium castra'' and ''castra hostium''; the latter is more common).<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 430.</ref> There are also stylistic differences between Latin authors; for example, while [[Julius Caesar|Caesar]] always writes ''castra pōnit'' 'he sets up camp', [[Livy]] more often writes ''pōnit castra''.<ref>Devine & Stephens (2006), p. 126.</ref>
There are however certain constraints; for example, in prose a monosyllabic preposition such as ''in'' 'in' generally precedes its noun (e.g. ''in Italiā'' 'in Italy').<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 432.</ref> Moreover, even though adjectives can both precede and follow the noun, there is a tendency for different kinds of adjectives to take different positions; for example adjectives of size usually come before the noun<ref>Walker (1918), p. 648.</ref><ref>H.J. Rose (1924)</ref> (''magnā vōce'' 'in a loud voice', rarely ''vōce magnā''), while 'modifiers that are more important than their noun or that specify it'<ref>Spevak (2014), pp. 212ff.</ref> (e.g. ''Via Appia'' 'the Appian Way') usually follow it.
To explain Latin word order there are two main schools of thought. One, represented by Devine and Stephens (2006), argues from the point of view of [[generative grammar]], and maintains that Latin prose has a basic underlying "neutral" word order, from which authors deviate for reasons of emphasis, topicalisation, rhythm, and so on. According to Devine and Stephens, the basic order in broad scope focus sentences is as follows:<ref>Devine & Stephens (2006), p. 79.</ref>
*Subject – Direct Object – Indirect Object / Oblique Argument – Adjunct – Goal or Source Argument – Non-Referential Direct Object – Verb
The other approach, represented by Panhuis (1982) and Olga Spevak (2010), examines Latin word order from the point of view of [[Functional theories of grammar|functional grammar]]. Rejecting the idea that there is a basic word order, this approach seeks to explain word order in terms of pragmatic factors, such as topic and focus, and semantic ones (1st person before 2nd, human before animals or things, agent before patient, etc.).<ref>Spevak (2010), pp. 2ff.</ref>
===Examples of word order=== {{see|Hyperbaton}}
The order of words is often chosen according to the emphasis required by the author. One way of emphasising a word is to reverse the usual order.<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 429.</ref> For example, in the opening sentence of [[Julius Caesar|Caesar]]'s ''Gallic War'', the usual order<ref>Walker (1918), p. 648.</ref> of numeral and noun ''trīs partīs'' 'three parts' is reversed to emphasise the number 'three': *''Gallia est omnis dīvīsa in partīs <u>trīs</u>''<ref>Caesar, ''B.G.'' 1.1.1</ref> :'Gaul, considered as a whole, is divided into <u>three</u> (parts)'
Another technique used by Latin authors is to separate a phrase and put another word or phrase in the middle, for example: *''<u>magnam</u> enim sēcum <u>pecūniam</u> portābat''<ref>Nepos, ''Hannibal'', 9.2.</ref> :'for he was carrying with him a <u>large sum of money</u>'
The technical term for this kind of separation is "[[hyperbaton]]" (Greek for 'stepping over'); it is described by Devine and Stephens as 'perhaps the most distinctively alien feature of Latin word order'.<ref>Divine & Stephens (2006), p. 524.</ref>
Placing the verb at or near the beginning of a clause sometimes indicates that the action is sudden or unexpected:<ref>Divine & Stephens (2006), p. 159.</ref> *''statim complūrēs cum tēlīs in hunc <u>faciunt</u> dē locō superiōre <u>impetum</u>''<ref>Cicero, ''Mil.'' 29.</ref> :'immediately several men, (armed) with weapons, <u>launch an attack</u> on my client from higher ground'
Splitting up an adjective-noun phrase and bringing the adjective to the beginning of the sentence can highlight it. In the following example from Cicero, the splitting of ''cruentum'' 'blood-stained' and ''pugiōnem'' 'dagger' creates a dramatic effect:<ref>Divine & Stephens (2006), p. 545.</ref> *''statim <u>cruentum</u> altē tollēns Brūtus <u>pugiōnem</u> Cicerōnem nōminātim exclāmāvit''<ref>Cicero, ''Phil.'' 2.28.</ref> :'immediately, raising high the <u>blood-stained dagger</u>, Brutus shouted out "Cicero" by name'
Considerations of rhythm and elegance also play a part in Latin word order.<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 429; Walker (1918), p. 652.</ref> For example, [[Pliny the Younger]] begins a letter as follows: *''magnum prōventum poētārum annus hic attulit''<ref>Pliny, ''Ep.'' 1.13.1</ref> :'it is a great crop of poets this year has brought'
In this sentence, the object (''magnum prōventum poētārum'' 'a great crop of poets') has been brought forward to highlight it. The other striking feature is the order ''annus hic'' for the more usual ''hic annus'' 'this year'. Two reasons which might be suggested are Pliny's fondness for ending a sentence with the rhythm − u − − u − <ref>"a clausula of cretic plus cretic, a favorite with Pliny": Selatie E. Stout, ''Scribe and Critic at Work in Pliny's Letters'' (1954), p. 150. (The symbol – stands for a long syllable, and u for a short one.)</ref> and also no doubt because of the elegant assonance of the vowels ''a-u-i a-u-i'' in the last three words.
==Gender and number== ===Gender and number agreement=== Latin has three genders (masculine, feminine, and neuter) and two numbers (singular and plural). Pronouns, adjectives, participles, and the numbers one to three have to agree in gender and number with the noun they refer to:
*Masculine : ''<u>hic</u> est fīlius <u>meus</u>'':<ref>Matt. 17.5</ref> 'this is my son' *Feminine : ''<u>haec</u> est fīlia <u>mea</u>'' : 'this is my daughter' *Neuter : ''<u>hoc</u> est corpus <u>meum</u>'':<ref>Matt. 26.26</ref> 'this is my body'
The same three genders are also found in the plural:
*Masculine : ''<u>hī</u> sunt fīliī <u>meī</u>'' : 'these are my sons' *Feminine : ''<u>hae</u> sunt fīliae <u>meae</u>'' : 'these are my daughters' *Neuter : ''<u>haec</u> <u>mea</u> sunt'':<ref>Virgil, ''Ec.'' 9.1</ref> 'these things are mine'
In Latin, words referring to males are always masculine, words referring to females are usually feminine.<ref>Kennedy (1930) [1871], pp. 14-15.</ref> (An exception is ''scortum'' (neuter) 'a whore'.) Words referring to things can be any of the three genders, for example ''mōns'' 'mountain' (masculine), ''arbor'' 'tree' (feminine), ''nōmen'' 'name' (neuter). However, there are certain rules; for example, nouns with the suffixes ''-a'' (unless referring to men), ''-tiō'', ''-tās'' are feminine; the names of trees, islands, and countries, such as ''pīnus'' 'pine', ''Cyprus'' 'Cyprus', and ''Aegyptus'' 'Egypt' are also usually feminine, and so on. Some nouns such as ''parēns'' 'parent' can vary between masculine and feminine and are called of "common" gender.<ref>The appendix of Kennedy's ''Revised Latin Primer'', pp. 221-225, has a series of rhymes to assist in learning the rules for gender.</ref>
When words of different genders are combined, the adjective is usually masculine if referring to people, neuter if referring to things:<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 183.</ref> *''patēr mihī et mātēr <u>mortuī</u> (sunt)'' (Terence)<ref>Terence, ''Eun.'' 518</ref> :'my father and mother are dead (''masc.'')' *''mūrus et porta dē caelō <u>tācta</u> erant'' (Livy)<ref>Livy, 32.29.1</ref> :'the wall (''masc.'') and gate (''fem.'') had been struck (''neut. pl.'') by lightning' (lit. 'touched from the sky')
However, sometimes the adjective may agree with the nearest noun.
==Latin cases== {{further information|Latin declension}} Nouns, pronouns, and adjectives in Latin change their endings according to their function in the sentence. The different endings are called different 'cases'. Case endings of a similar kind are also found in other languages, such as Ancient and Modern Greek, German, Russian, Finnish, Sanskrit, Armenian and Turkish.<ref>Blake, Barry (1994). ''Case''. Cambridge Textbooks in Linguistics: Cambridge University Press.</ref>
The six cases most commonly used in Latin and their main meanings are given below. The cases are presented here in the order which has been used in Britain and countries influenced by Britain ever since the publication of [[Benjamin Hall Kennedy|Kennedy]]'s Latin Primer in the 19th century,<ref>Christopher Stray (1996), ''Grinders and Grammars: A Victorian Controversy'' (The Textbook Colloquium).</ref> as opposed to the traditional order – Nom, Gen, Dat, Acc, Voc, Abl – still used in the United States and most European countries:
*Nominative : ''is rēx'' : 'that king' (Subject, or Complement (e.g. 'he is that king')) *Vocative : ''ō rēx!'' : 'o king!' *Accusative : ''eum rēgem'' : 'that king' (Object, or Goal) *Genitive : ''eius rēgis'' : 'of that king' *Dative : ''eī rēgī'' : 'to that king', 'for that king' *Ablative : ''eō rēge'' : 'with that king' (also 'by, from, in')
(A small line, called a macron, over a vowel indicates that it is pronounced long.)
Another case is the Locative, which is used mostly with the names of cities (e.g. ''Rōmae'' 'in Rome') and a very limited number of ordinary nouns (e.g. ''domī'' 'at home').
===Examples of case use=== {{further information|Ablative (Latin)}}
For the most part the use of cases is quite straightforward. The following examples from [[Julius Caesar|Caesar]] show the cases in use in a basic sense: *''Cūriō <u>Mārcium</u> <u>Uticam</u> <u>nāvibus</u> praemittit''<ref>Caesar, ''Bell. Civ.'' 2.24.1.</ref> :'Curio (Nom.) sends ahead Marcius (Acc.) to Utica (Acc.) with the ships (Abl.)'
Here ''Cūriō'' as subject of the verb is nominative, ''Mārcium'' as direct object is accusative; ''Uticam'' is also accusative as it is the goal or object of motion; and ''nāvibus'' 'with the ships' has the ablative ending, which means 'with'.
*''Pompeius ... <u>Lūceriā</u> proficīscitur <u>Canusium</u>''<ref>Caesar, ''Bell. Civ.'' 1.24.1</ref> :'Pompey (Nom) <u>from Luceria</u> (Abl) sets out <u>to Canusium</u> (Acc)'
Here ''Pompeius'' is subject (Nom.), ''Lūceriā'' shows another meaning of the ablative ending, namely 'from', and ''Canusium'' is again accusative of goal. Note that with names of cities there is no need to add a preposition such as ''ad'', but the accusative case alone indicates 'to'.
*''Caesar ... <u>mīlitibus</u> <u>signum</u> dedit''<ref>Caesar, ''Bell. Gall.'' 7.27.</ref> :'Caesar (Nom) gave a signal (Acc.) <u>to the soldiers</u> (Dat)'
Here ''mīlitibus'', although it shares the same ending as the ablative ''nāvibus'' in the previous example, is clearly dative, meaning 'to or for the soldiers' (usually when a noun has an ambiguous ending such as ''-īs'', ''-ibus'' or ''-ēbus'' it will be interpreted as dative if it is a person, ablative if it is a thing).
===Idioms using the dative case=== However, the description of the use of cases is not always simple. The classification of the uses of the dative alone takes up nearly twelve pages in Woodcock's ''A New Latin Syntax''<ref>Woodcock (1959), pp. 38-50.</ref> and ten pages in Gildersleeve and Lodge.<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), pp. 218-230.</ref> For example, when asking someone's name, a Roman would say: *''quid est <u>tibī</u> nōmen?'' ([[Plautus]])<ref>Plautus, ''Pseud.'' 634 and 639; ''Pre.'' 697; ''Trin.'' 886.</ref> :'what's your name?' (lit. 'what is <u>for you</u> name?'')
This is an example of the Dative of Possession, as in: *''<u>illī</u> ... duae fuēre fīliae'' (Plautus)<ref>Plautus, ''Poen.'' 84</ref> :'he had two daughters' (lit. '<u>to him</u> there were two daughters')
Another surprising idiomatic use is the "Dative of the Person Affected": *''nihil equidem <u>tibī</u> abstulī'' (Plautus)<ref>Plautus, ''Aul.'' 635; cf. Gildersleeve and Lodge (1895), p. 219.</ref> :'I haven't stolen anything from you' (lit. '<u>for you</u>')
The dative is also used with verbs of fighting with someone:<ref>Kühner & Stegmann (1912), p. 319.</ref> *''nōlī pugnāre <u>duōbus</u>'' (Catullus)<ref>Catullus 62.64</ref> :'don't fight with (lit. 'for') two people at once'
Another idiom is the "Predicative Dative" used with the verb 'to be' in phrases such as ''ūsuī esse'' 'to be of use', ''labōrī esse'' 'to be a trouble (to someone)'.<ref>Woodcock (1959), pp. 48-9.</ref> *''nēminī meus adventus <u>labōrī</u> aut <u>sūmptuī</u> ... fuit'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, Ver. 2.1.16; cf. Woodcock (1959), p. 48.</ref> :'my arrival was a <u>trouble</u> or <u>expense</u> for no one'
Many verbs also which in English take a direct object are used in Latin intransitively with a dative noun or pronoun, e.g. ''persuādeō'' 'I persuade', ''crēdō'' 'I believe', ''resistō'' 'I resist'.<ref>Woodcock (1959), pp. 41-2.</ref> *''nōn persuāsit <u>illī</u>'' (Seneca)<ref>Seneca, ''Ep.'' 70.10</ref> :'he did not persuade him (lit. 'for him')' *''imperāvit <u>eī</u>'' (Nepos)<ref>Nepos, ''Hann.'' 12</ref> :'he ordered him' ('gave an order to him')
===Prepositions=== Frequently, to make the meaning more precise, a noun in the accusative or ablative is preceded by a preposition such as ''in'' 'in, into', ''ad'' 'to', ''cum'' 'with', or ''ex'' 'out of'. This is especially so if the noun refers to a person. For example: *''ad rēgem'' (Acc) 'to the king' (used with a verb of motion such as 'goes' or 'sends') *''ā rēge'' (Abl.) 'by the king', 'from the king' *''cum eō'' (Abl.) 'with him' *''ex urbe'' (Abl.) 'from/out of the city'
However, when the meaning of an accusative or an ablative is clear (for example ''Canusium'' (Acc) 'to Canusium', ''nāvibus'' (Abl) 'with the ships', ''posterō diē'' (Abl) 'on the following day'), the case ending alone is sufficient to give the meaning. Unlike in Greek, prepositions are not used in Latin with the dative or genitive.
====Prepositions with accusative or ablative==== Four prepositions can be followed by more than one case, depending on their meaning. These are ''in'' 'in' (Abl), 'into' (Acc.); ''sub'' 'under' (Abl.), 'to the foot of' (Acc.); ''super'' 'over, above' (Acc.), 'concerning' (Abl.); and ''subter'' 'under' (usually with Acc.)<ref>Greenough et al. (1903), pp. 131-136.</ref> *''in urbem'' (Acc) 'into the city' *''in urbe'' (Abl) 'in the city'
====Position of prepositions==== Prepositions almost always precede their noun or pronoun, except that ''cum'' 'with' follows a personal pronoun, e.g. ''mēcum'' 'with me' and sometimes a relative pronoun (''quīcum'', ''quōcum'' and ''cum quō'' are all possible for 'with whom').<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 267.</ref> There are occasional exceptions, especially with two-syllable prepositions after pronouns,<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 267.</ref> e.g. ''haec inter'' (Virgil)<ref>Virgil, ''Aen.'' 8.671.</ref> 'in the midst of these'.
Sometimes when the noun has an adjective it is placed before the preposition for emphasis, e.g. ''magnā cum cūrā'' 'with great care' (Cicero),<ref>Cicero, ''Inv.'' 1.50</ref> but this is not an invariable rule.<ref>Walker (1918), p. 651-2.</ref> Occasionally also the opposite order (noun-preposition-adjective) may be used in poetry and later prose,<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 267, note 1</ref> e.g. ''silvā lupus in Sabīnā'' (Horace)<ref>Horace, ''Car.'' 1.22.9</ref> 'a wolf in the Sabine forest', or ''metū in magnō'' (Livy) 'in great fear'.<ref>Livy, 9.37.11.</ref>
==Latin tenses== {{further information|Latin conjugation}} Latin has six main tenses in the indicative mood, which are illustrated below using the verb ''facere'' 'to make' or 'to do': *Present : ''faciō'' : 'I do', 'I am doing' *Future : ''faciam'' (2nd person ''faciēs''): 'I will do', 'I will be doing' *Imperfect : ''faciēbam'' : 'I was doing', 'I used to do', 'I began to do' *Perfect : ''fēcī'' : 'I did', 'I have done' *Future Perfect : ''fēcerō'' : 'I will have done' *Pluperfect : ''fēceram'' : 'I had done'
The verb ''sum'' 'I am', which is irregular, has the tenses ''sum'', ''erō'', ''eram'', ''fuī'', ''fuerō'', ''fueram''. Some verbs (conjugations 1 and 2) instead of the Future ''-am'', ''-ēs'', ''-et'' etc. have a different future ending in ''-bō'', ''-bis'', ''-bit'', e.g. ''amābō'' 'I will love'.
To these six ordinary tenses may be added various "periphrastic" tenses, made from a participle and part of the verb ''sum'' 'I am', such as ''factūrus eram'' 'I was about to do'.<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 88.</ref>
For the most part these tenses are used in a fairly straightforward way; however, there are certain idiomatic uses that may be noted.<ref>See Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), pp. 154-167.</ref>
===Use of the tenses=== ====Present==== The present tense can refer to a current situation: *''Senātus haec intellegit; Cōnsul videt; hic tamen vīvit'' (Cicero)<ref>CIcero, ''in Cat.'' 1.2.</ref> :'the Senate understands this; the Consul sees it; yet this man is still alive' *'''tū fortasse vērum dīcis'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero ''Academica Pos.'' 2.</ref> :'perhaps you are telling the truth'
It can also refer to an event which takes place at the moment of speaking: *''veniō nunc ad Dorylēnsium testimōnium'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''pro Flacco'' 39.</ref> :'I come now to the testimony of the Dorylensians'
The present tense is often used in narrative in a past sense, especially when the writer is describing an exciting moment in the story. This is known as the 'historic present': *''videt imminēre hostēs ... capit arma a proximīs ...''<ref>Caesar, B.C. 6.38.</ref> :'he sees the enemy threatening ... he immediately seizes weapons from those next to him ...'
After ''dum'' 'while', the present has an imperfect meaning: *''dumque <u>fugit</u>, tergō vēlāmina lāpsa relīquit'' (Ovid)<ref>Ovid, ''Met'' 4.55</ref> :'while she was fleeing, her cloak (''vēlāmina'') slipped from her back (''tergō'') and she left it behind'
The present can sometimes mean 'has been doing', usually with a length of time and ''iam'' 'now':<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), pp. 157, 159.</ref> *''is Lilybaeī multōs iam annõs <u>habitat</u>'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Verr.'' 2.4.38.</ref> :'he has been living in Lilybaeum for many years now'
====Future==== The future tense can describe an event or a situation in the near or distant future: *''ibī cōtīdiē tuās litterās exspectābō'' (Cicero) :'when I get there, I shall be expecting your letters every day' *''īnsequentī librō explicābō'' (Vitruvius) :'I will explain this in the next book'
After ''cum'' 'when' or ''sī'' 'if' referring to a future time, usually<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), pp. 156.</ref> the future is used where English has a present tense: *''nārrābō cum aliquid <u>habēbō</u> novī'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''ad Att.'' 5.6.2.</ref> :'I will tell you when I have some news' (lit. 'I will have')
====Imperfect==== The imperfect tense can describe a situation that used to take place regularly or habitually: *''multum enim illum <u>audiēbam</u>'' (Cicero) :'I used to listen to him a lot'
It can also describe a situation that was temporarily taking place at a particular moment: *''senex dīcitur eam fābulam, quam in manibus <u>habēbat</u>, recitāsse iūdicibus'' (Cicero) :'the old man is said to have recited the play, which he was holding (at that moment) in his hands, to the judges'
Another use is to describe what someone was trying to do, or intending to do, or about to do, but which never actually took place:<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), pp. 158.</ref> *''Cūriam relinquēbat'' (Tacitus)<ref>Tacitus, ''Ann.'' 2.34</ref> :'he was on the point of leaving the Senate house'
When used with ''iam'' and a length of time it means 'had been doing': *''quod iam diū <u>cupiēbant</u>'' (Livy)<ref>Livy, 24.29</ref> :'which they had been desiring for a long time now'
Sometimes in letters a writer imagines himself in the position of the recipient and uses a past tense to describe an event which for the writer himself is present:<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), pp. 166-7.</ref> *''etenim ibī sedēns haec ad te <u>scrībēbam</u>'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Att.'' 1.10 (6)</ref> :'as a matter of fact I was sitting there as <u>I was writing</u> this to you' (i.e. 'I am sitting there as I write this to you')
====Perfect==== The perfect most frequently narrates an event in the past: *''ūniversī ex nāvī <u>dēsiluērunt</u>'' (Caesar) :'all at the same time, <u>they leapt down</u> from the ship'
The perfect can also be used like the English present perfect ('I have done'):<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 159.</ref> *''ecum et mūlum Brundisī tibī <u>relīquī</u>'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Fam'', 16.9.3.</ref> :'<u>I have left</u> a horse and a mule for you at Brundisium'
The three verbs ''ōdī'' 'I hate', ''meminī'' 'I remember', and ''nōvī'' 'I know', are used in the perfect tense but have the meaning of a present tense: *''<u>meminī</u> mē adesse'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Fin.'' 2.55</ref> :'<u>I remember</u> that I was present' *''<u>ōdī</u> et amō'' (Catullus) :'<u>I hate</u> and I love'
The perfect, not the imperfect, is used when a situation is said to have lasted in the past for a certain length of time, unless ''iam'' 'now' is added:<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 158.</ref> *''diū ... silentium <u>fuit</u>'' (Livy)<ref>Livy 7.10.1</ref> :'for a long time <u>there was</u> silence' *''multōs annōs nostrae domī <u>vīxit</u>'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Tusc''. 5.113</ref> :'<u>he lived</u> in our house for many years'
The perfect ''fuit'' 'it was once', 'it used to be' is also used for a situation which is no longer in existence: *''statua Attī ... ad laevam cūriae <u>fuit</u>'' (Livy)<ref>Livy, 1.36.5</ref> :'there was once a statue of [[Attus Navius|Attus]] to the left of the senate house'
The perfect is also necessary in sentences such as the following, which describe a permanent state, as opposed to the imperfect, which describes a temporary one:<ref>Pinkster (1990), p. 238, §11.3.1.</ref> *''Samia mihī māter <u>fuit</u>; ea habitābat Rhodī.''<ref>Terence, ''Eun.'' 107</ref> :"My mother <u>was</u> a Samian; <u>she was living</u> in Rhodes (at that time)."
The perfect must also be used with adverbs such as ''semel'' 'once', ''bis'' 'twice', ''ter'' 'three times', which imply that the situation is now over:<ref>Pinkster (1990), p. 223, §11.1.3.</ref> *''<u>fuī</u> bis in Bīthȳniā'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Planc.'' 84.</ref> :'<u>I have been</u> twice in Bithynia'
====Future perfect==== The future perfect is usually used in a sentence with 'if' or 'when', but it can sometimes be used on its own, as in the following sentence: *''Pompōnia, tū invīta mulierēs, egō virōs accīverō'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''ad Att.'' 5.1.3.</ref> :'Pomponia, you invite the women, and (meanwhile) I will have summoned the men'
There is also an idiom using the future perfect of ''videō'':<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 163.</ref> *''vōs <u>vīderītis</u> quod illī dēbeātur'' (Livy)<ref>Livy, 1.58.10.</ref> :'you must see to it what is due to that man'
More frequently it is found after ''sī'' 'if' or ''cum'' 'when'. The future perfect is used when the event in the 'if' clause will precede the main verb:<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), pp. 373; 380-381</ref> *''moriēre, sī <u>ēmīserīs</u> vōcem!'' (Livy)<ref>Livy 1.58.3.</ref> :'you will die, if you utter a sound!' (lit. 'if you will have uttered')
====Pluperfect==== The pluperfect can be used as in English to describe an event that had happened earlier than the time of the narrative: *''quae gēns paucīs ante mēnsibus ad Caesarem lēgātōs mīserat'' (Caesar)<ref>Caesar, ''B.C.'' 3.80.1.</ref> :'this nation had sent ambassadors to Caesar a few months previously'
The pluperfect of ''ōdī'', ''nōvī'' and ''meminī'' has the meaning of an imperfect: *''nōn <u>nōverat</u> Catilīnam; Āfricam tum praetor ille obtinēbat'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Cael.'' 10</ref> :'he did not know [[Catiline]], since the latter was at that time governor of Africa'
==Passive and deponent verbs== ===Passive tenses=== In addition to the [[active voice]] tenses listed above, Latin has a set of passive voice tenses as follows: *Present : ''capior'' : 'I am captured', 'I am being captured' (by someone or something) *Future : ''capiar'' (2nd singular ''capiēre'' or ''capiēris'') : 'I will be captured' *Imperfect : ''capiēbar'' : 'I was being captured', 'I used to be captured' *Perfect : ''captus sum'' : 'I was captured', 'I have been captured' *Future Perfect : ''captus erō'' : 'I will have been captured' *Pluperfect : ''captus eram'' : 'I had been captured'
The three perfect tenses (Perfect, Future Perfect, and Pluperfect) are formed using the perfect participle together with part of the verb ''sum'' 'I am'. The ending of the participle changes according to the gender and number of the subject: ''captus est'' 'he was captured'; ''capta est'' 'she was captured'; ''captī sunt'' 'they were captured', and so on.
===The use of passive verbs=== A passive verb is generally used when it is unnecessary to indicate who did the action: *''[ille] sē hostibus obtulit atque <u>interfectus est</u>.''<ref>Caesar, B.G. 4.12.6</ref> :'he offered himself to the enemy and was killed'
When it is desired to show the agent or person(s) by whom the action was done, Latin uses the preposition ''ab'' or ''ā'' with the ablative case: *''arx <u>ab hostibus</u> capta est'' (Livy)<ref>Livy, 9.24</ref> :'the citadel has been captured by the enemy!'
When the agent is not a person but a thing, no preposition is used, but simply the ablative case: *''Trōes tē miserī, <u>ventīs</u> maria omnia vectī, ōrāmus'' (Virgil)<ref>Virgil, ''Aeneid'' 1.520.</ref> :'we, wretched Trojans, carried over all the seas by the winds, beg you'
===Passive of 'give'=== In Latin, unlike English, only the direct object (not the indirect object) of an active verb can be made the subject of a passive verb.<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 152.</ref> It is not correct to say in Latin 'the soldiers were being given their pay' but only 'pay was being given to the soldiers': *''mīlitibus stīpendium (dabātur)'' (Livy)<ref>Livy, 1.12</ref> :'pay was being given to the soldiers'
===Impersonal passive=== Another unusual feature of Latin, compared with English, is that intransitive verbs such as ''eō'' 'I go', ''veniō'' 'I come', ''pugnō'' 'I fight' and ''persuādeō'' (+ dative) 'I persuade' can be made passive, but only in a 3rd person singular impersonal form:<ref>Woodcock (1959), p. 43.</ref> *''<u>ītur</u> in antīquam silvam'' (Virgil)<ref>Virgil, ''Aen.'' 6.179</ref> :'they go into an ancient forest' (lit. 'going is done') *''septimō diē Carthāginem <u>ventum est</u>'' (Livy)<ref>Livy, 26.42</ref> :'on the seventh day they reached Carthage' *''<u>persuāsum erat</u> Cluviō ut mentīrētur'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Q.Rosc.'' 51.</ref> :'Cluvius had been persuaded to lie' (literally: 'it had been persuaded to Cluvius that he should lie')
===Passive infinitive=== The infinitive of a passive verb ends in ''-ī'' (3rd conjugation) or ''-rī'' (other conjugations): ''capī'' 'to be captured, ''audīrī'' 'to be heard', etc. *''in vincula <u>dūcī</u> iubet'' (Livy)<ref>Livy, 3.49.2.</ref> :'he ordered him to be put in chains' *''sī vīs <u>amārī</u>, amā'' (Seneca)<ref>Seneca, ''Ep.'' 9.6.</ref> :'if you wish to be loved, love'
The Perfect passive has an infinitive ''captus esse'' 'to have been captured', and there is also a rarely used Future passive infinitive made using the supine (''captum'') plus the passive infinitive ''īrī'': ''captum īrī'' 'to be going to be captured'. It is typically used in indirect statements: *''<u>occīsum īrī</u> ab ipsō Milōne videō'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Att.'' 4.2.4.</ref> :'I can see that he is going to get killed by Milo himself'
===Deponent verbs=== Most of the verbs ending in ''-or'' are true passives in meaning (i.e. they represent actions which are done ''by someone'' or ''by something''). However, there are a few which are ambivalent and can be either active or passive in meaning, such as ''vertor'' 'I turn' (intransitive) or 'I am turned', ''volvor'' 'I revolve' (intransitive) or 'I am rolled': *''<u>vertitur</u> intereā caelum et ruit Ōceanō nox'' (Virgil)<ref>Virgil, ''Aen.'' 2.250</ref> :'meanwhile the sky <u>turns</u> and night falls upon the Ocean'
In addition, there are a few verbs such as ''proficīscor'' 'I set out', ''polliceor'' 'I promise', ''cōnor'' 'I try' which despite their passive endings have an active meaning. These verbs (which have no active counterpart) are called [[deponent verb]]s:<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), pp. 110-114.</ref> *''ipse in Italiam <u>profectus est</u>'' (Caesar)<ref>Caesar, ''B.G.'' 3.35.2</ref> :'he himself <u>set out</u> for Italy'
Although most deponent verbs are intransitive, some of them such as ''sequor'' 'I follow' can take a direct object: *''hunc <u>sequī</u> sē iubet'' (Nepos)<ref>Nepos, ''Alc.'' 10.5</ref> :'he ordered this man <u>to follow</u> him'
Deponent verbs are frequently used in their perfect participle form (e.g. ''profectus'' 'having set out'): *''mediā nocte <u>profectus</u> ad hostium castra māne pervēnit''<ref>Caesar, B.G. 7.18.2.</ref> :'after setting out at midnight, he reached the enemies' camp in the early morning'
==The subjunctive mood== As well as the indicative mood illustrated above, which is used for stating and asking facts, and an imperative mood, used for direct commands, Latin has a [[subjunctive mood]], used to express nuances of meaning such as 'would', 'could', 'should', 'may' etc. (The word ''mood'' in a grammatical sense comes from the Latin ''modus'', and has no connection with the other meaning of 'mood', in the sense of 'emotional state', which comes from a Germanic root.)<ref>Woodcock (1959), p. 83.</ref>
===Formation of the subjunctive=== There are four tenses of the subjunctive, which in the verb ''faciō'' are as follows: *Present : ''faciam'' (2nd person ''faciās'') : 'I may do', 'I would do', 'I should do' (also simply 'I do') *Imperfect : ''facerem'' : 'I would be doing', 'I should do' (in a past context) (also simply 'I was doing') *Perfect : ''fēcerim'' : 'I have done', 'I did' *Pluperfect : ''fēcissem'' : 'I would or should have done' (also 'I had done')
The present subjunctive of 1st conjugation verbs ends in ''-em'' instead of ''-am'': ''amem'' 'I may love, I would love'.
The present subjunctive of the verbs ''sum'' 'I am', ''possum'' 'I am able', ''volō'' 'I want', ''nōlō'' 'I don't want' and ''mālō'' 'I prefer', ends in ''-im'': ''sim'' 'I may be, I would be', ''possim'' 'I may be able', ''velim'' 'I would like, I may wish', etc.
The imperfect subjunctive of every verb has the same form as the infinitive + ''-m'': ''essem'', ''possem'', ''vellem'', ''amārem'', ''vidērem'', ''īrem'' etc.
===Uses of the subjunctive=== The subjunctive has numerous uses, ranging from what potentially might be true to what the speaker wishes or commands should happen. It is often translated with 'should', 'could', 'would', 'may' and so on, but in certain contexts, for example indirect questions or after the conjunction ''cum'' 'when' or 'since', it is translated as if it were an ordinary indicative verb.
Often in English the subjunctive can be translated by an infinitive; for example, ''imperāvit ut īret'' (literally, 'he ordered <u>that he should go</u>') becomes in more idiomatic English 'he ordered him <u>to go</u>'.
====Potential subjunctive==== The 'potential' subjunctive is used when the speaker imagines what potentially may, might, would, or could happen in the present or future or might have happened in the past. The negative of this kind is ''nōn'':<ref>Woodcock (1959), p. 89.</ref> *''dūrum hoc fortasse <u>videātur</u>'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Ver.'' 2.5.7.</ref> :'this <u>may</u> perhaps <u>seem</u> harsh'
*''quid si hoc <u>fēcissem</u>?'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''de Inventione'' 2.140.</ref> :'what if I had done this?'
*''nōn facile <u>dīxerim</u> quicquam mē vīdisse pulchrius''<ref>Cicero, ''Verr.'' 2.4.94.</ref> :'I couldn't easily say (= I don't think) that I have ever seen anything more beautiful'
====Optative subjunctive==== Another use is for what the speaker wishes may happen, or wishes had happened (the 'optative' subjunctive). The negative of this kind is ''nē'':<ref>Woodcock (1959), p. 87.</ref> *''utinam iam <u>adesset</u>!'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Fam.'' 11.25.2</ref> :'if only he were here already!'
*''utinam ille omnīs sēcum suās cōpiās <u>ēduxisset</u>!'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''In Cat.'' 2.4.</ref> :'if only he had taken out all his forces with him!'
====Jussive subjunctive==== It can also represent what the speaker commands or suggests should happen (the 'jussive' subjunctive).<ref>Woodcock (1959), p. 85.</ref> The negative is again ''nē'': *''<u>vīvāmus</u>, mea Lesbia, atque <u>amēmus</u>'' (Catullus)<ref>Catullus, 5.1.</ref> :'<u>let's live</u>, my Lesbia, and <u>let's love</u>'
*''nē ... mortem <u>timuerītis</u>''<ref>Cicero, ''Tusc.'' 1.98.</ref> :'you should not fear death'
===In indirect statements and questions=== One important use of the subjunctive mood in Latin is to indicate that the words are quoted; this applies for example to subordinate clauses in indirect speech:<ref>Woodcock (1959), pp. 223ff.</ref> *''locum ubi <u>esset</u> facile inventūrōs'' (Nepos)<ref>Nepos, ''Hann.'' 12.3</ref> :'(he said that) they would easily find the place where <u>he was</u>'
It also applies to all indirect questions: *''quārē id <u>faciam</u>, fortasse requīris'' ([[Catullus]])<ref>Catullus 85</ref> :'perhaps you ask why <u>I do</u> this'
When used in indirect speech or in an indirect question, the subjunctive is translated as if were the corresponding tense of the indicative.
===Subjunctive after conjunctions=== The subjunctive mood is very frequently used in subordinate clauses following conjunctions.
====After ''cum''==== Used with the indicative, the conjunction ''cum'' means 'at that time when', or 'whenever':<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), pp. 370-373.</ref> *''cum tacent, clāmant'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Cat.'' 1.21</ref> :'when they are silent, (it is as if) they are shouting'
Used with the subjunctive, however, it frequently means 'at a time when'.<ref>Woodcock (1959), pp. 187ff.</ref> When ''cum'' is used with the Imperfect subjunctive, a common way of translating it is 'while': *''cum <u>sedērem</u> domī trīstis, accurrit Venerius'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Ver.'' 2.4.32.</ref> :'while I was sitting sadly at home, Venerius suddenly came running up'
With the Pluperfect subjunctive, it often means 'after X happened': *''cum excessisset Aegyptō Antiochus, lēgātī ... Cyprum nāvigant'' (Livy)<ref>Livy, 45.12.</ref> :'after Antiochus had left Egypt, the ambassadors sailed to Cyprus'
It can also mean 'in view of the fact that' or 'since':<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), pp. 374-5.</ref> *''quae cum ita <u>sint</u>''<ref>Cicero, ''Dom''. 142 et passim</ref> :'in view of the fact that these things are so' / 'since this is so'
Another, less common, meaning is 'though':<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 375.</ref> *''nihil mē adiūvit, cum <u>posset</u>'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Att.'' 9.13.8</ref> :'he did nothing to help me, though (or: at a time when) he could have done'
====After ''ut''==== When followed by the indicative, the conjunction ''ut'' can mean 'as' (e.g. ''ut fit'' 'as generally happens') or 'as soon as' or 'when' (''ut vēnī'' 'as soon as I came'). But with the subjunctive ''ut'' has the meaning 'that' or 'so that'.
It can represent purpose ('so that he could...'):<ref>Woodcock (1959), pp. 108ff.</ref> *''Crētam vēnit ut ibī quō sē cōnferret <u>cōnsīderāret</u>'' (Nepos)<ref>Nepos, ''Hann.'' 9.1.</ref> :'(Hannibal) came to Crete so that there <u>he could consider</u> (in order to consider) where he should go to next'
It can also be used to introduce an indirect command ('that he should...'):<ref>Woodcock (1959), pp. 101ff.</ref> *''imperāvit eī ut omnēs forēs aedificiī <u>circumīret</u>'' (Nepos)<ref>Nepos, ''Hann.'' 12.4</ref> :'he ordered him to go round (lit. 'that he should go round') all the doors of the building'
It can also represent result (making what is known as a "consecutive" clause):<ref>Woodcock (1959), pp. 114ff.</ref> *''idque sīc aedificāverat ut in omnibus partibus aedificiī exitūs <u>habēret</u>'' (Nepos)<ref>Nepos, ''Hann.'' 12.3</ref> :'and he had built it in such a way that in all parts of the building it had exits'
Occasionally ''ut'' with the subjunctive can mean 'although'.<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 392.</ref>
====After ''sī''==== After ''sī'' 'if', the subjunctive expresses an imagined or unreal situation: *''quod, sī <u>interfectus essem</u>, accidere nōn <u>potuisset</u>'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Sest''. 49</ref> :'which, if I had been killed, could not have happened'
*''sī <u>revīvīscant</u> et tēcum <u>loquantur</u>, quid <u>respondēres</u>?'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Fin.'' 4.22.61; cf Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 384.</ref> :'if they were to come to life and talk to you, what answer would you be making?'
====After ''nē''==== After ''nē'' 'that not', the subjunctive can express a negative purpose: *''hīnc nē exīre <u>posset</u>, ephorī valvās obstrūxērunt'' (Nepos)<ref>Nepos, ''Paus.'' 5.2.</ref> :'so that <u>he would not be able</u> to escape from here, the [[ephor]]s blocked up the doors'
It can also introduce a negative indirect command: *''nē propius sē castra <u>movēret</u> petiērunt'' (Caesar)<ref>Caesar, ''B.G.'' 4.9.1</ref> :'they requested him not to move his camp any nearer to them'
The conjunction ''nē'' can also express a fear; in this case, the word 'not' must be omitted from the English translation:<ref>Woodcock (1959), pp. 144-147.</ref> *''verēns nē <u>dēderētur</u>'' (Nepos)<ref>Nepos, ''Hann.'' 9.1</ref> :'fearing that <u>he might be handed over</u> to the enemy'
====After ''dum''==== When used with the indicative, ''dum'' means 'while' or 'as long as'. But when followed by the subjunctive, it often means 'until':<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 367.</ref> *''Verginius dum collēgam <u>consuleret</u> morātus (est)'' (Livy)<ref>Livy 4.21.10</ref> :'Verginius waited until he had a chance to consult his colleague'
Another meaning is 'provided that':<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 368.</ref> *''ōderint dum <u>metuant</u>'' ([[Lucius Accius|Accius]])<ref>Accius, quoted in Cicero, ''Off.'' 1.28.97</ref> :'let them hate, provided that they fear'
====After ''priusquam''==== The conjunctions ''priusquam'' and ''antequam'' both mean 'before (something happened)'. If the event actually happened, the verb is usually in the indicative mood; but when the meaning is 'before there was a chance for it to happen', the verb is subjunctive:<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), pp. 369-370</ref> *''(collem) celeriter, priusquam ab adversāriīs <u>sentiātur</u>, commūnit'' (Caesar)<ref>Caesar, ''B.C.'' 1.54.4</ref> :'he fortified the hill quickly, before it could be noticed by the enemies'
====After ''quīn''==== The conjunction ''quīn'' (literally, 'how should it not be?') is always used after a negative verb or the equivalent, typically 'there is no doubt that', 'who does not know that...?', and so on. The words following ''quīn'' are always positive and usually state what was actually the case:<ref>Woodcock (1959), pp. 141-4; Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), pp. 356-357.</ref> *''nōn dubitō quīn ad tē omnēs tuī <u>scrīpserint</u>'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Fam.'' 5.8.1</ref> :'I have no doubt that all your friends will have written to you' *''quis ignōrat quīn tria Graecōrum genera <u>sint</u>?'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Flacc.'' 64</ref> :'who does not know that there are three kinds of Greeks?'
Another usage is after a negative verb such as 'I can't help doing' or 'he did not refrain from doing': *''facere nōn possum quīn ... tibī grātiās agam'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Fam.'' 10.24.1 (letter from Plancus)</ref> :'I can't do otherwise than to thank you' *''Antiochus nōn sē tenuit quīn contrā suum doctōrem librum <u>ēderet</u>'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Ac.'' 2.4.12</ref> :'Antiochus did not refrain from publishing a book against his own teacher'
Equally it can be used in sentences of the kind 'A didn't happen without B also happening': *''nūllum adhūc intermīsī diem quīn aliquid ad tē litterārum <u>darem</u>'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Att.'' 7.15.1</ref> :'up to now I have not let a day go past without dropping you a line'
In sentences like the following, there is potential for confusion, since the ''quīn'' clause, though positive in Latin, is translated in English with a negative: *''nēmo fuit militum quīn <u>vulnerārētur</u>'' (Caesar)<ref>Caesar, ''B.C.'' 3.55.3</ref> :'there was not one of the soldiers who was not wounded' *''fierī nūllō modō poterat quīn Cleomenī <u>parcerētur</u>'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Verr.'' 5.104</ref> :'it was quite impossible that Cleomenes would not be spared'
In the following context, the words after ''quīn'' express not what actually happened but what very nearly happened: *''neque multum āfuit quīn castrīs <u>expellerentur</u>'' (Caesar)<ref>Caesar, ''B.C.'' 2.35.4</ref> :'nor were they far from being expelled from the camp'
===Subjunctive after ''quī'' 'who'=== ====Generic==== The pronoun ''quī'' 'who' or 'which', when followed by a subjunctive, can mean 'a person such as' (generic):<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 353.</ref> *''quī modestē <u>pārat</u>, vidētur quī aliquandō <u>imperet</u> dignus esse'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Leg.'' 3.2.5</ref> :'he who obeys modestly, seems to be the sort of person who one day is worthy to rule'
====Purpose==== It can also mean 'in order to' (purpose):<ref>Woodcock (1959), p. 109.</ref> *''lēgātōs Rōmam quī auxilium <u>peterent</u> mīsēre'' (Livy)<ref>Livy, 5.35.4</ref> :'they sent ambassadors to Rome to ask for help'
====Explanatory==== Another meaning is 'in view of the fact that' (giving an explanation), as in the following example, said jokingly of a [[consul]] who was elected on the last day of the year:<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 406.</ref> *''fuit mīrificā vigilantiā, quī suō tōtō cōnsulātū somnum nōn <u>vīderit</u>'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero ''Fam''. 7.30.1</ref> :'(Caninius) was of amazing vigilance, in view of the fact that he didn't see any sleep in the whole of his consulate!'
====Reported speech==== Another reason for using the subjunctive after ''quī'' is to show that the words of the ''quī'' clause are quoted or part of indirect speech:<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 402.</ref> *''Paetus omnīs librōs quōs frāter suus <u>relīquisset</u> mihī dōnāvit'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, Att. 2.1.12 </ref> :'Paetus made a gift to me of all the books which his brother had left him'
Clearly here Paetus had written or stated "I am giving you all the books which my brother left me", and Cicero is quoting his words indirectly to Atticus.
==The imperative mood== ===Ordinary imperative=== The [[imperative mood]] is used for giving direct orders. The active form can be made plural by adding ''-te'': *''<u>dā</u> mī bāsia mīlle, deinde centum!'' (Catullus)<ref>Catullus 5.</ref> :'give me a thousand kisses, then a hundred!' *''<u>date</u> dexterās fidemque!'' (Livy)<ref>Livy 1.58.7</ref> :'give me your right hands and your oath!'
===Deponent imperative=== [[Deponent verb]]s such as ''proficīscor'' 'I set out' or ''sequor'' 'I follow' have an imperative ending in ''-re'' or -''minī'' (plural): *''patent portae: <u>proficīscere</u>!'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Cat.'' 1.10</ref> :'the gates are open: depart!' *''<u>sequiminī</u> mē hūc intrō ambae'' ([[Terence]])<ref>Terence, ''Hec.'' 793</ref> :'follow me this way inside, both of you'
===Negative commands=== An imperative is usually made negative by using ''nōlī(te)'' (literally, 'be unwilling!') plus the infinitive. However, in poetry an imperative can sometimes be made negative with the particle ''nē'': *''<u>nōlīte</u> mīrārī'' ([[Seneca the Elder]])<ref>Seneca the Elder, ''Controv.'' 7.7.2</ref> :'don't be surprised' *''<u>nē</u> mē <u>terrēte</u> timentem, obscēnae volucrēs!'' (Virgil)<ref>Virgil, Aen. 12.875</ref> :'do not terrify me, who am already scared, obscene birds!'
A negative order can also use the perfect subjunctive:<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 173.</ref> *''dē mē nihil timuerīs'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Att.'' 4.17.4.</ref> :'do not be afraid on my account'
===Future imperative=== Latin also has a Future imperative or 2nd imperative,<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 174.</ref> ending in ''-tō(te)'', used to request someone to do something at a future time, or if something else happens first: *''sī quid acciderit, ... <u>scrībitō</u>'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Att.'' 10.1.3</ref> :'if anything happens, write to me'
This imperative is very common in early writers such as Plautus and Cato:
*''ubi nōs lāverimus, sī volēs, <u>lavātō</u>'' (Terence)<ref>Terence, ''Eunuchus'', 592.</ref> :'when we have finished washing, get washed if you wish'.
*''crūdam si edēs, in acētum <u>intinguitō</u>.'' (Cato)<ref>Cato, ''de Agri Cultura'' 156.</ref> :'if you eat it (cabbage) raw, dip it in vinegar.'
Some verbs have only the Second Imperative, for example ''scītō'' 'know', ''mementō'' 'remember'.<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 174.</ref>
The 3rd person of this imperative is used in laws:
*''iūsta imperia <u>suntō</u>, īsque cīvēs ... <u>pārentō</u>'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''de legibus'' 3.6.</ref> :'orders must be just, and citizens must obey them'
===Other ways of expressing a command=== Other requests are made with expressions such as ''cūrā ut'' 'take care to...', ''fac ut'' 'see to it that...' or ''cavē nē'' 'be careful that you don't...'<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 176.</ref> *''<u>cūrā</u> ut valeās'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Att.'' 6.3.9.</ref> :'make sure you keep well'
The future indicative can be used for polite commands:<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 162.</ref> *''Pīliae salūtem <u>dīcēs</u> et Atticae'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Att.'' 16.6.4.</ref> :'will you please give my regards to Pilia and Attica?'
==The infinitive== Although often referred to as a 'mood',<ref>e.g. Allen & Greenough (1903), p. 262</ref> the Latin infinitive is usually considered to be a verbal noun rather than a mood.<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 167; Woodcock (1959), p. 14.</ref>
Latin has three infinitives in the active voice, and three passive. Since ''faciō'' is irregular in the passive ('to be done' is ''fierī'', taken from the verb ''fīō'' 'I become'), they are here shown using the verb ''capiō'' 'I capture':
Active: *Present : ''capere'' : 'to capture, to be capturing' *Perfect : ''cēpisse'' : 'to have captured' *Future : ''captūrus esse'' : 'to be going to capture'
Passive: *Present : ''capī'' : 'to be captured' *Perfect : ''captus esse'' : 'to have been captured' *Future : ''captum īrī'' : 'to be going to be captured'
The infinitives of ''sum'' 'I am' are ''esse'', ''fuisse'', and ''futūrus esse'' (often shortened to ''fore''). ''Possum'' 'I am able' has ''posse'' and ''potuisse'', ''volō'' 'I want' has ''velle'' and ''voluisse''. Neither of these verbs has a Future infinitive, and the Present infinitive is used instead.<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 334, note 3.</ref>
The Future infinitive is used only for indirect statements (see below).<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 331, note 3.</ref>
The passive Future infinitive is rare, and is frequently replaced with a phrase using ''fore ut''.<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 334.</ref>
===Uses of the infinitive=== The infinitive can be used as the subject, complement, or the object of a verb:<ref>Kennedy, p. 162.</ref> *''<u>vīvere</u> est <u>cōgitāre</u>'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero ''Tusc.'' 5.111</ref> :'to live is to think' *''<u>errāre</u>, <u>nescīre</u>, <u>dēcipī</u> ... turpe dūcimus'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Off.'' 1.18</ref> :'we consider <u>to be in error</u>, <u>to be ignorant</u>, <u>to be deceived</u> as something shameful'
===Prolative infinitive=== It can also be used, as in English, dependent on an adjective, or with verbs such as ''possum'' 'I am able' or ''volō'' 'I want': *''dulce et decōrum est prō patriā <u>morī</u>'' (Horace)<ref>Horace, ''Carm.'' 3.2</ref> :'it is a sweet and glorious thing <u>to die</u> for one's country'
*''nōn possum haec <u>ferre</u>'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Att.'' 7.2.7</ref> :'I can't bear it'
It is likewise used, as in English, with verbs such as ''iubeō'' 'I order', ''vetō'' 'I forbid', ''patior'' 'I allow', ''volō'' 'I want' and so on, where the main verb takes an object in the accusative case: *''volō tē hoc <u>scīre</u>'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero ''Att.'' 1.18.6</ref> :'I want you to know this'
However, other verbs of similar meaning, such as ''imperō'' 'I order', ''persuādeō'' 'I persuade', and ''hortor'' 'I urge', are not used with an infinitive, but with ''ut'' and the subjunctive mood: *''hortātur mē <u>ut</u> senātūi <u>scrībam</u>'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Fam.'' 10.31.4</ref> :'he is urging me to write to the senate' (lit. 'that I should write')
===Historic infinitive=== An infinitive or a succession of infinitives is sometimes used to represent a rapid or confused series of actions:<ref>Woodcock (1959), p. 15.</ref> *''<u>clāmāre</u> omnēs'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Verr.'' 2, 2, 188</ref> :'everyone <u>began shouting at once</u>'
===Accusative and infinitive=== A very common use of the infinitive in Latin, in which it differs from English, is its use for indirect statements, that is for sentences where a subordinate clause is dependent on a main verb such as 'he says', 'he knows', 'he pretends', 'he believes', 'he thinks' and so on. In Latin, instead of 'they pretend that they want', the idiom is to say 'they pretend themselves to want': *''sē pācem <u>velle</u> simulant'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Att.'' 14.15.2</ref> :'they pretend that they want peace'
Similarly 'I'm glad you've arrived safely' becomes 'I am glad you to have arrived safely': *''salvom tē advēnisse gaudeō'' (Terence)<ref>Terence, ''Ph.'' 286</ref> :'I am glad you have arrived safely'
In this construction, the subject of the infinitive (''sē'', ''tē'' in the above examples) is in the accusative case.
So common is this construction in Latin, that often the verb 'he said' is simply omitted if it is clear from the context, the accusative and infinitive alone making it clear that the statement is reported: *''rem atrōcem <u>incidisse</u>'' (Livy)<ref>Livy 1.58.5</ref> :'a terrible thing had happened (she said)'
===Other ways of expressing 'that'=== Not every subordinate clause which starts with the conjunction 'that' in English is translated with an accusative and infinitive. In some contexts ''ut'' with the subjunctive is required, for example after a verb of happening:<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 355.</ref> *''accidit cāsū <u>ut</u> lēgātī Prūsiae Rōmae ... <u>cēnārent</u>'' (Nepos)<ref>Nepos, ''Hann.'' 12.1</ref> :'it happened by chance that some ambassadors of King Prusias were dining in Rome'
In other circumstances a clause with ''quod'' 'the fact that' is used with the indicative:<ref>Gildersleeve & Lodge (1895), p. 329.</ref> *''praetereō <u>quod</u> eam sibī domum <u>dēlēgit</u>'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Cluent.'' 66.188</ref> :'I omit the fact that he chose that house for himself'
This type of clause with ''quod'' (which became ''que'' in modern French, Portuguese and Spanish and ''che'' in Italian) gradually took over from the Accusative and infinitive construction and became the usual way of expressing indirect speech in modern [[Romance languages]] which are descended from Latin.
==Participles== Unlike Greek, Latin is deficient in participles, having only three, as follows:<ref>Woodcock (1959), p. 71.</ref> *Present : ''faciēns'' (pl. ''facientēs'') : 'doing' *Perfect : ''factus'' : '(having been) done' *Future : ''factūrus'' : 'going to do'.
Thus, there is no passive present or future participle, and no active past participle. In deponent verbs, however, the Perfect participle is active in meaning, e.g. "profectus", 'having set out', "conatus" 'having tried'.
The verb ''sum'' 'I am' has no Present or Perfect participle, but only the Future participle ''futūrus'' 'going to be'.
The Romans themselves<ref>[[Aelius Donatus|Donatus]] ''Ars Minor: de participio''; Quintilian 9.3.9.</ref> considered the gerundive (see below) also to be a participle, but most modern grammars treat it as a separate part of speech.
===Uses of participles=== ====Adjectival participle==== Participles have endings like those of adjectives, and occasionally they are used as though they were adjectives. If so, they refer to the state or condition that a thing or person is in:<ref>Woodcock (1959), p. 77.</ref> *''aquā <u>ferventī</u> ... perfunditur'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Ver''. 2.1.67</ref> :'he was doused with <u>boiling</u> water'
*''<u>occīsōs</u> sepelīvit'' ([[Eutropius (historian)|Eutropius]])<ref>Eutropius, 2.11</ref> :'he buried the <u>dead</u> (those who had been killed)'
====Participle as a verb==== More frequently, however, a participle is more like a verb, and if one action follows another, it can often replace the first of two verbs in a sentence: *''Caesar Cascae bracchium <u>arreptum</u> graphiō trāiēcit'' ([[Suetonius]])<ref>Suetonius, ''Jul.'' 82.2</ref> :'Caesar <u>grabbed</u> [[Servilius Casca|Casca]]'s arm and stabbed it with his writing instrument'
Literally, 'Caesar with his writing instrument (''graphiō'') stabbed the arm (''bracchium''), which had been grabbed, for Casca' (''Cascae'' here is probably Dative of the Person Affected.)
Participles can frequently be translated into English using a clause with 'when':
*<u>quaerenti</u>que viro 'satin salve?' 'minime' inquit.<ref>Livy, 1.58.7</ref> :'and <u>when</u> her husband <u>asked</u> "Are you all right?", she said "No!"
*''<u>cōnātus</u>que prōsilīre aliō vulnere tardātus est'' (Suetonius)<ref>Suetonius, ''Jul.'' 82.2</ref> :'and <u>when he tried</u> to leap forward he was slowed down (''tardātus'') by another wound'
'-ing' and 'who' are other possible translations: *''<u>currēns</u> Lepta vēnit'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Fam.'' 3.7.4</ref> :'Lepta came <u>running</u>'
*''<u>strīctō</u> gladiō, ad <u>dormientem</u> Lucrētiam vēnit'' (Livy)<ref>Livy, 1.52.8</ref> :'<u>drawing</u> his sword, he came to Lucretia, <u>when she was sleeping</u> / <u>who was sleeping</u>'
Apart from 'when' and 'who', other translations are possible, such as 'if', 'since', or 'although':<ref>Woodcock (1959), p. 73.</ref> *''oculus sē nōn <u>vidēns</u>, alia cernit'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''T.D.'' 1.67</ref> :'<u>although it can't see</u> itself, the eye discerns other things'
A participle phrase can also stand for a noun clause, as in the following example:<ref>Woodcock (1959), pp. 75-6.</ref> *''<u>captī</u> oppidī signum ex mūrō tollunt'' (Livy)<ref>Livy, 4.34.1</ref> :'they raised a sign from the wall that the town <u>had been captured</u>' (lit. 'of the town having been captured')
Normally a Present participle represents an action which is simultaneous with the main event ('he came running'), and a Perfect participle represents one which has already happened ('after drawing his sword'). In the following example, however, the Perfect participle represents the result following the main action: *''crīnīs scindit ... <u>solūtōs</u>'' (Virgil)<ref>Virgil, ''Aen.'' 12.870</ref> :'she tore her hair, <u>making it loose</u>'
Participles are much commoner in Latin than in English. Sometimes multiple participles can be used in a single sentence: *''noctū lūmine <u>appositō</u> <u>experrēcta</u> nūtrīx animadvertit puerum <u>dormientem</u> <u>circumplicātum</u> serpentis amplexū. quō aspectū <u>exterrita</u> clāmōrem sustulit.'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Div.'' 1.79</ref> :'in the night, in the light of a lamp <u>placed nearby</u>, the nurse, <u>who had woken up</u>, noticed that the boy, <u>while he was sleeping</u>, <u>had been wrapped around</u> with the coils of a snake; <u>terrified</u> by this sight, she raised a cry'
====Ablative absolute==== The phrase ''strīctō gladiō'' (lit. 'with drawn sword') above is an example of a common idiom in which a noun and participle are put in the Ablative case to represent the circumstances of the main event. This idiom is referred to as an "ablative absolute" and is comparable to the Greek [[genitive absolute]] or the English [[nominative absolute]].<ref>Woodcock (1959), p. 73-4.</ref> Other examples are: *''in hostēs <u>signō datō</u> impetum fēcērunt'' (Caesar)<ref>Caesar, ''Gal.'' 1.52.3</ref> :'when the signal was given (lit. 'with signal given'), they made an attack on the enemy' *''at pater Aenēas, <u>audītō nōmine Turnī</u>, dēserit mūrōs'' (Virgil)<ref>Virgil, ''Aeneid'' 12.697.</ref> :'but Father Aeneas, on hearing Turnus's name, immediately deserted the walls'
The present participle can also be used in an ablative absolute: *''at illa <u>audientibus nōbīs</u> 'ego ipsa sum' inquit 'hīc hospita' ''(Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''ad Att.'' 5.1.3.</ref> :'but she, while we were listening, said "I am just a guest here myself!"' *''nec imperante nec sciente nec praesente dominō'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''in Milonem'' 29.</ref> :'without their master ordering it, or knowing, or even present'
The verb ''sum'' ('I am') has no participle, except in the compound forms ''absēns'' 'absent' and ''praesēns'' 'present'. To make an ablative absolute with 'to be', the words are put in the ablative, and the verb is simply omitted: *''puerulō mē'' (Nepos)<ref>Nepos, ''Hannibal'' 2.3</ref> :'when I was a little boy' *''hīs cōnsulibus Fīdēnae obsessae, Crustumeria capta'' (Livy)<ref>Livy, 2.19.2</ref> :'when these men were consuls, Fidenae was besieged and Crustumeria captured'
==The gerundive== {{further information|Gerundive}}
The gerundive is a verbal adjective ending in ''-ndus'' (''-nda'' etc. if feminine). It is usually passive in meaning (although a few [[deponent verb]]s can form an active gerund, such as ''secundus'' 'following' from ''sequor'' 'I follow').<ref>Woodcock (1959), p. 158.</ref> The usual meaning of the gerundive is that it is necessary for something to be done. Often the word 'must' is a suitable translation: *''nunc est <u>bibendum</u>'' ([[Horace]])<ref>Horace, ''Carm.'' 1.37</ref> :'now it is necessary to drink' (i.e. 'now we must drink') *''Catō inexpiābilī odiō <u>dēlendam</u> esse Carthāginem ... prōnūntiābat'' ([[Florus]])<ref>Florus 1.31.15.4</ref> :'[[Cato the Elder|Cato]] with implacable hatred used to declare that [[Carthage]] must be destroyed'
If a word is added to show by whom the action must be done, this word is put in the dative case (e.g. ''nōbīs'' 'for us').<ref>Woodcock (1959), p. 158.</ref>
Because it is passive in meaning, the gerundive is usually formed from transitive verbs. However, intransitive verbs such as ''eō'' 'I go' and ''persuādeō'' 'I persuade', which can be used passively in an impersonal construction, can also have an impersonal gerundive, ending in ''-um'':<ref>Woodcock (1959), p. 159.</ref> *''mihī Arpīnum <u>eundum</u> est'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, 13.9.2</ref> :'It is necessary for me to go to Arpinum' / 'I have to go to [[Arpino|Arpinum]]' *''<u>persuādendum</u> iūdicī est'' ([[Quintilian]])<ref>Quntilian, 7.3.15</ref> :'the judge has to be persuaded'
The gerundive after ''ad'' can also be used to express purpose (a use which it shares with the gerund, see below):<ref>Woodcock (1959), p. 164.</ref> *''L. Septimium tribūnum militum ad <u>interficiendum</u> Pompeium mīsērunt'' (Caesar)<ref>Caesar, ''Civ.'' 3.104.2</ref> :'they sent the military tribune Lucius Septimius <u>to kill</u> [[Pompey]]' *''hunc Dātamēs vīnctum ad rēgem <u>dūcendum</u> trādit Mithridātī'' (Nepos)<ref>Nepos, ''Dat.'' 4.5</ref> :'[[Datames]] handed this man over in chains to Mithridates for him <u>to be led</u> to the King'
==The gerund== The gerund is a verbal noun ending in ''-ndum'' (accusative), ''-ndī'' (genitive), or ''-ndō'' (dative or ablative). Although identical in form to a neuter gerundive, and overlapping the gerundive in some of its uses, it is possible that it has a different origin.<ref>Woodcock (1959), p. 159</ref>
Gerunds are usually formed from intransitive verbs,<ref>Woodcock (1959), p. 159.</ref> and are mainly used in sentences such as the following where the meaning is 'by doing something', 'of doing something', or 'for the purpose of doing something'. A gerund is never used as the subject or direct object of a verb (the infinitive is used instead). *''<u>veniendō</u> hūc exercitum servāstis'' (Livy)<ref>Livy, 7.35; ''servāstis'' is a contraction of ''servāvistis''.</ref> :'<u>by coming</u> here, you have saved the army' *''aqua nitrōsa ūtilis est <u>bibendō</u>'' (Pliny the Elder)<ref>Pliny ''N.H.'' 31.32.59</ref> :'alkaline water is good <u>for drinking</u>' *''idōneam ad <u>nāvigandum</u> tempestātem'' (Caesar)<ref>Caesar, ''B.G.'' 4.23.1</ref> :'weather suitable (''idōneam'') for <u>sailing</u>' *''<u>sacrificandī</u> causā, Delphōs ēscendī'' (Livy)<ref>Livy, 42.42</ref> :'for the sake <u>of sacrificing</u>, I climbed up to [[Delphi]]'
Occasionally a gerund can be made from a transitive verb and can take a direct object:<ref>Woodcock (1959), pp. 161-2</ref> *''subabsurda <u>dīcendō</u> rīsūs moventur'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''de Or.'' 2.289</ref> :'<u>by saying</u> incongruous things laughs (''rīsūs'') are raised'
They can also be formed from deponent verbs such as ''ingredior'' 'I enter': *''aliīs timor hostium audāciam flūmen <u>ingrediendī</u> dedit'' (Livy)<ref>Livy, 22.56</ref> :'for others fear of the enemy gave them the boldness (''audāciam'') to enter (lit. <u>of entering</u>) the river'
However, if the verb is transitive, a phrase made of noun + gerundive is often substituted for the gerund:<ref>Kennedy, p. 165.</ref> *''lignum āridum māteria est idōnea <u>ēliciendīs ignibus</u>'' (Seneca)<ref>Seneca, ''N.Q.'' 2.22.1</ref> :'dry wood (''lignum'') is a suitable material <u>for striking fire</u>'
==The supine== The supine is a rarely used part of the verb ending in ''-tum'' or (in some verbs) ''-sum''. Although it is identical with the accusative case of verbal nouns such as ''adventus'' 'arrival', ''mōtus'' 'movement', etc., it differs from them in that it is a verb as well as a noun, and can sometimes take a direct object.
===Supine in -um=== The supine is normally used to express purpose, when combined with a verb of movement such as ''eō'' 'I go' or ''mittō'' 'I send': *''<u>lūsum</u> it Maecenās, <u>dormītum</u> ego Vergiliusque'' (Horace)<ref>Horace, ''Serm.'' 1.5.48</ref> :'[[Maecenas]] goes <u>to play</u> a game, Virgil and I <u>to sleep</u>' *''<u>spectātum</u> veniunt, veniunt spectentur ut ipsae'' (Ovid)<ref>Ovid, ''Ars'' 1.1.99</ref> :'(the girls) come <u>to watch</u>, but they also come so that they can be looked at themselves'
In the following example it takes a direct object: *''lēgātōs ad Caesarem mittunt <u>rogātum</u> auxilium'' (Caesar)<ref>Caesar, ''B.G." 1.11.2</ref> :'they send ambassadors to Caesar <u>in order to ask for</u> help'
The accusative of the supine is also used to make the rare future passive infinitive ''<u>captum</u> īrī'' 'to be going to be captured', which can be used in indirect statements referring to the future (see above):<ref>Woodcock (1959), pp. 112-3</ref> *''ante reditum eius negōtium confectum īrī putō'' (Cicero)<ref>Cicero, ''Att.'' 11.16.1.</ref> :'I think the business will be completed before his return'
===Supine in -u=== There is another form of the supine, an Ablative in ''-ū'', found with certain verbs only. But this cannot take an object.<ref>Kennedy, p. 167</ref> It is used in phrases such as ''mīrābile dictū'' 'amazing to say', ''facile factū'' 'easy to do':<ref>Woodcock (1959), p. 112.</ref> *''<u>dictū</u> quam rē facilius est'' (Livy)<ref>Livy, 40.35.13</ref> :'it is easier <u>in the saying</u> than in reality'

revision.text:
'''Mathew Mattam''' (1950/1 – 29 May 2016) was a [[Malayalam]] writer who authored about 300 novels. His novels were regularly published in ''[[Mangalam Weekly]]'', ''[[Manorama Weekly]]'' and other Malayalam periodicals. ''Anchu Sundarikal, Alippazham, Daivam Urangiyittilla, Profasarude Makal'', ''Lakshamveedu'' and ''Roti'' are some of his major works. Two of his popular works - ''[[Karimbu]]'' and ''[[May Dinam]]'' - were made into movies. He died aged 65.<ref>{{cite web|title=Popular Malayalam novelist Mathew Mattam no more|url=http://english.manoramaonline.com/news/just-in/popular-malayalam-novelist-mathew-mattam-dies-kerala.html|publisher=''Malayala Manorama''|date=May 29, 2016|accessdate=May 29, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Novelist Mathew Mattam passes away|url=http://english.mathrubhumi.com/mobile/news/kerala/novelist-mathew-mattam-passes-away-english-news-1.1093366|publisher=''Mathrubhumi''|date=May 29, 2016|accessdate=May 29, 2016}}</ref>
==Major works== * ''Mazhavillu'' (മഴവില്ല്) * ''Policekarante Makal'' (പോലീസുകാരന്റെ മകള്‍) * ''Veendum Vasantham'' (വീണ്ടും വസന്തം) * ''Nisagandhi'' (നിശാഗന്ധി) * ''Onpatham Pramaanam'' (ഒന്‍പതാം പ്രമാണം) * ''Kaivishom'' (കൈവിഷം) * ''Manavatti'' (മണവാട്ടി) * ''Daivam Urangiyittilla'' (ദൈവം ഉറങ്ങിയിട്ടില്ല) * ''Thadankal Palayam'' (തടങ്കല്പ്പാളയം) * ''Karimbu'' (കരിമ്പ്) * ''Profasarude Makal'' (പ്രൊഫസറുടെ മകള്‍) * ''Anchu Sundarikal'' (അഞ്ചു സുന്ദരികള്‍) * ''Alippazham''(ആലിപ്പഴം) * ''Roti'' (റൊട്ടി) * ''May Dinam'' (മെയ് ദിനം) * ''Lakshamveedu'' ലക്ഷം വീട്)

'''Máel Sechlain Mac Áeda''' was the [[Archbishop of Tuam]] 1312 – 10 August 1348.
==Background== Máel Seachlainn Mac Áeda was a member of a [[Connacht]] family associated with the [[Kings of Connacht]]. They were natives of [[Maigh Seóla]], near [[Tuam]], and originally of the [[Clann Cosgraigh]], which was a branch of the [[Uí Briúin]] and kin to the [[Muintir Murchada]].
The surname is nowadays rendered McHugh, or more rarely, McCoy.
==Episcopal career== Mac Áeda was elected archbishop of Tuam about March 1312, but not [[translated]] from [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Elphin|Elphin]] until 19 December 1312, and did not receive possession of the [[temporalities]] until 1 April 1313. Also known as Malachais Tuamensis or Malachi MacHugh, he died in 1348.
==Leabhair Mac Áeda== He wrote what was described by O'Reilly as ''"a large volume of [[miscellaneous]] matter in Irish, containing, amongst other things, a catalogue of Irish kings from Niall Naoighiallach ([[Niall Noígíallach]]) to Roderick O'Conor ([[Ruaidrí Ua Conchobair]]). [[Sir James Ware]], in his account of Irish writers, says, it was extant in his time, and called the Book of Mac Aodha. We can not say where it is to be found at present."''
==Death== His death does not seem to be recorded in any of the extant [[Irish annals]]. The cause of his death is unknown, but it may be related to [[The Black Death]] which was prevalent in Ireland at the time. The [[Annals of Connacht]] state that ''"A great plague raged in Ireland ... by which great numbers were carried off."''
==Genealogy==
* ''Genealach Mec Aodha/'''The genealogy of Mac Aodha''': Donnchadh s. '''Maol Eachlainn, the archbishop''', s. Maol Eachlainn s. Donnchadh s. Aodh s. Tadhg s. Muireadhach s. Aodh s. Ruaidhrí s. Coscrach s. Flann Abhradh s. Gamhnán s. Conaing s. Muirgheas s. Coscrach Mór s. Donn s. Cumasach s. Dúnghal s. Ceann Faoladh s. Colga s. Aodh s. Seanach s. Duach Teangumha s. Fearghus s. Muireadhach Mál (the king) s. Eóghan Sréabh s. Duach Galach s. [[Brión mac Echach Muigmedóin|Brian]].''
From [[Leabhar na nGenealach]], 201.6, pp. 442–43, volume I.
==See also== * [[McHugh]] * [[Crichaireacht cinedach nduchasa Muintiri Murchada]] * [[Ruaidhri Mac Aedha]], Lord of Clan Cosgraigh, died 1170 * [[Máelsechlain Mac Áeda]], died 1270 * Denis Mac Áeda, son of Aedh Mac Áeda, [[Dean of Tuam]], died 1339 * [[Paddy McHugh]], [[Independent (politician)|Independent]] [[Teachta Dála|T.D.]], born 1953 * Ann Maire McHugh, 9/11 victim
